I was surprised by how much I enjoyed Barakamon, given that I normally watch romantic anime, but I kept coming across it so I thought I'd give it a try, and I'm so glad that I did! This anime gave me happy, almost nostalgic feelings when I watched it and I was sad when it finished. The artwork is beautiful and had a light, airy feeling. The main character, Hanada, is at times awkward and insecure, but in a relatable, likeable way. The real star of the show is the little girl named Naru, who had me laughing the entire time! I loved Hanada's affectionfor her, and how she caused him to grow. I wish there were more episodes, and I plan on reading the manga, which is ongoing. If you are considering watching this anime, go ahead and give it a try... you won't be disappointed! Oh, and if it matters at all I loved the opening and ending songs; they were so pretty!

I have finally made the right choice to send off summer 2014. If you are wondering why I didn't review the remaining anime that I have watched is because I have nothing interesting to say and I always repeat myself every time I do that, which is frustrating. So to end summer 2014 on a good note, I decided to review Barakamon, the #1 anime of summer 2014, in my opinion. 
STORY (10):
The story follows Seishu Handa, a calligrapher expert, who was sent to Goto Island, near Kyushu, after having a feud with an elderly curator due to the fact that Seishu Handa couldn't takecriticism from him. From there, Seishu Handa, develops a relationship with the group from Goto Island. 


The story has its funny and sad moments bundled together. Just like the korean movie that I had watched which was "My Teacher, Mr. Kim". 


ART (9):


The animation is excellent.


SOUND (10):


The melody of the song fits in well. Like when there is sad moments, the tune is sad. Likewise if there are funny moments, the tune is exciting. It sets the mood perfectly. The opening and ending are addictive.


CHARACTER (10):


The characters are well-fleshed out and have ample time of development. 


Seishu Handa was my favorite character. He reminded me so much of Hachiman Hikigaya from Oregairu, in a better way. Seishu Handa was the type of character who is determined, optimistic, wise, everything that I wanted from him. Daisuke Ono did a good job in portraying the voice of Seishu Handa. I did like his character development the best, it shows that he learns his mistake by improving as a character from there on.


Naru Kotoshi was the best comic relief character. She brings joy to the cast especially form a strong bond with Seishu Handa. She is also funny when she does all those funny faces.


Hiroshi Kido was also an interesting character. He prepares food for the gang and he is also a likeable person.


Tamako and Miya were both interesting characters and I like the way how they support Seishu in what he does.


I also did like most of the cast but none of the stand out compared to the characters that I have mentioned. I wish these characters would at least have some development so that I can give them the better recognition.


CONCLUSION (10):


This anime broke my heart for the 1st time I watched because I felt for the characters. This anime also teaches us a lot of quotes like


"A hero lies in everyone"

"Everyone has different talents"

"Learning is a journey, not a destination"


Learning is a journey, and because we learn and develop by observing our mistakes and learn from there. Especially when it comes to criticism. If we want to become better, we have to take criticism so that we can improve and become better persons in the near future. 


I will never regret watching Barakamon. I enjoyed this anime to the fullest. I love the comedic moments and the emotional moments this anime has bundled together. The chemistry and bond between characters are strong and I love this anime to death. Barakamon will forever stay true in my heart and so I give this anime a 10/10. 2 thumps up.


If you love slice-of-life, please watch this anime. You will feel all the emotions in this anime.

Summary(If you don't want detailed analysis) : Barakamon is just one of those anime that makes you feel happy inside, the characters are lovable, the art is beautiful despite the story being a bit lacking in conclusion. Although this is a slice of life anime, so that's to be expected. The overall environment brought by Barakamon really gives a warmth to the viewers heart. When you see everyone in the small village pitching in when someone needs help, it really makes you think that living in somewhere like that would be paradise.
*Edit*: After re-watching this anime I realized that the anime really is a greatfeel-good anime and probably my favorite slice of life anime ever.


Story: The story of Barakamon isn't that great, like most slice of life anime. The calligraphy part is really interesting though, and a unique spin on the slice of life genre. The story leaves in an open ended style which could be good and could be bad depending, although the story really isn't what makes this anime so great.

8/10


Art: The art in Barakamon is really amazing, Seishuu Handa is a really good calligrapher. (Oh God that joke was bad) Jokes aside, all the characters look amazing in the anime and the scenery also looks nice. Since it is in the country the art is able to capture the trees, insects and the buildings really nicely and in my opinion Barakamon has one of the best art styles of all time.

10/10


Sound: The soundtrack of Barakamon has a really cheerful part to it. It is sort of similar to My Neighbor Totoro, in terms of the soundtrack, but also has its own unique parts to it. It is one of those soundtracks that you would want to play in the background of your life.

9/10 


Character: In my opinion characters are really the make of break of an anime for me. In Barakamon the characters are its strongest suite. Over the course of the anime all of the characters develop around each other and learn from each other. This really makes the anime all that much better. Character development in this anime goes at a good pace and makes you fall in love with the characters, and feel empathy and joy alongside them.


Enjoyment: Overall Barakamon is probably my favorite slice of life anime and made it to my top 3 favorites of all time. Sometimes I feel like newer anime is just generic and already been done 1000 times. But it's anime like this that  are the reason I watch anime. 

10/10


Overall rating 10/10

Story & Characters:
Barakamon is an absolute gem and deserves every bit of praise and popularity that it gets. The way it builds its world and characters is nothing short of magic, weaving a big but lovable cast of three dimensional humans who are just living out their mundane lives and through doing so, gradually discover new things about themselves. Character interactions and dynamics are extremely entertaining, oftentimes heartwarming. Its not so much the setting as it is the characters that make this show, and fuck me if the characters aren't believable, well written, and well developed. There's not much else I can say about Barakamon'ssimple but immensely enjoyable story because that's the magic of Barakamon: its premise is deceptively unimpressive on paper, but once you start watching it, you will feel the effectiveness of its writing seep through your very soul, and be reminded once again of why you even started watching anime as an entertainment medium in the first place.


Art:

Kinema Citrus did an amazing job with its character designs, animation, and color palette - everything on the island looks vibrant and full of life. The facial expressions are all perfect and convey all the right emotions at all the right times. It's truly great stuff.


Sound:

Both the openings and endings are topgun. They perfectly capture the show's joyful energy and sense of wonder. The background tracks that play during each episode are usually very mellow and easy-going, fitting right in with the mood of the anime.


Enjoyment:

Just sit back, relax, and feel the magic of Barakamon's simple but profound and touching writing.


Overall:

10/10 very few slice-of-life shows have managed to contain as much heart and soul and Barakamon, and I doubt we will see anything so deep and genuine like it again for a quite a long time.

I will start by stating Barakamon is a great anime. I know the term is used very often these days but trust me when I say it has "a one of a kind" type of quality to it. I took up this show on a suggestion of a friend and it was a pure pleasure to watch it. The only downside is that it only lasted 12 episodes (so far). I will make my review spoiler free :)
The story aspect is very well thought out. The progression feels very natural and content. The comedy is a class on its own mostly due to its integrationof a difference in dialect, a small girls who misunderstands a lot, and the various well written main and side characters. The setting of the plot gives the story a larger room to roam thus creating a great environment for a comedy slice of life show. 


The art in my opinion is great. I gave it a 9/10 even though the amount of detail isn't very high such as Hyouka but the the art of the main character writing calligraphy is great to watch. The art styling of the characters are also pleasant to watch and felt very natural in its settings. Art was a very important aspect in a show like this and they pulled it off without a hitch. 


For the sound I give it a 9/10 as well I know I seem to be rating it very high but if you do listen to the soundtrack individually you will see the amount of details put into each tune. I loved the opening sequence music as well as the opening sequence as a whole. The whole sound track feels very at home with the show and does not feel out of place. It blends well with the scenes and at most times it is very subtle but it creates the right atmosphere all the time. 


Now for the best part about the show. The characters were an absolute delight to watch! I loved Naru (the little girl) her childlike curiosities, her mannerism, her comedic timing, her thoughtfulness, her ideals, and the innocence is such a joy to watch. The main character Handa (calligrapher) was also very well written. He has the most amount of character growth throughout the series (which is obvious since he is the main guy) but they don't rush his growth. They acknowledge that even with enlightenment there can be downfalls which I feel was a very human trait missing in many shows. His progression throughout the show was great to watch and his comedic essence was great! The side characters such as Miwa, Tama, and Hiroshi provided great laughs as well as brought out the best in the main character at times. Their drive and integration into the show provided many memorable moments. 


The enjoyment throughout the entire series was very very good. Outstanding! The laughs that will cause you to catch your breath and stomachs to burst are aplenty. The understanding and bonds formed between all the characters are a pleasure to watch. The enlightenment in life lived was very raw, down to earth and relate-able. 


Overall I thoroughly enjoyed this series. It was a great treat to watch and because of my sheer enjoyment of it I decided to write a review regarding it. I hope it provides as much joy to you as it did to me. 


This is my second review please do let me know how I can improve on my review writing. Thank you and enjoy! :)

You can't produce good things of you are not happy in your life. And moreover, you will produce better things if you have a good feeling in what you do.
That's the spirit of the anime. Reality is not quite far from that, of course others things have to be takes in considerations.
Well anyway. I'll write the script, without spoilers (maybe I have to really go deeper in the detail to spoil, thing that I'm not going to do obviously).
Seishu Handa, more known as Sensei in the show, is the principal character. He practices calligraphy, in Tokyo. The story start when he punch the conservator ofthe museum, which said that his calligraphic is basic, no story in it (and you know, all the things that "specialists" can detect in the art of someone). His father decides to launch him on the Goto isle, to keep out all these things of his mind, and decompress a bit.

On this isle, he will discover all the people who live here. This is a small village, so you know, the difference is pretty hard (at the beginning he can't even understand what people are saying).

He also continues to do calligraphy, and try to take the first place in the expositions.

So, during the show, we see him with all the people in the village, and his progression in his work.


I appreciate this show. Of course it's really more funny than serious, but I think there also is some work by the author on the messages that he wanted to share. And... Well, it's a success. I mean, it's not boring to watch, you laugh a bit, and you take good time.

So, why 7? Because for me 7 isn't a bad mark (1 is a bad mark), and I think there's nothing transcendent in this show, it's not very impressive. You'll not say "WOAAA" when something happen, because... Because you will not be surprised at all maybe.


Let's see a bit in details.


Story: 7/10

It comes from a good idea. And it's a good idea. But the script just takes twenty lines, maybe not more. You'll not be exciting to see what will going on after each episode, like in Steins;Gate for example (of course this is two different category). It's a good story, nothing more, nothing less.

Art: 9/10

Well, I'm forced to say that it's a good point of the show. It's well designed. You'll like to watch it, because it's pretty good.

Sound: 8/10

I really liked the opening! At the moment when I wrote these lines, I have it in my head! It's a good music, and I think it fit well the theme of the show. The ending is also good, but I have no feeling like I have with the opening.

For the rest of the sound, it's good enough.

Characters: 7/10

Most of the characters are adolescents. It's interesting and it gives a funny part to the anime. Sensei has also a good behaviour, a bit classic, but it's not bad.

At least there's nothing really impressive. That's why I put 7.

Enjoyment: 7/10

Well, it was good! It's a bit hilarious; there are some good scenes that I will remember maybe. It makes me thinking a bit. Because I really think that the author wants to give to the spectator some messages, like I said in the beginning. And also that you need one thing in your life to be happy: friends. No importance to who they are, how they are. If you appreciate them and have good times with them, stay with them.

I think this show succeed well to give to the spectator this impression, that's why I liked it.


If you are sceptical, maybe you should not. If you like funny shows, and if you don't have like 3000 show to see, you can go for it. Also if you want to take a break between two serious shows, go for it you won't be disappointed I think.


But trust me about one thing: make up your own opinion by watching this show. Don’t believe everyone.

You only live once, but if you do it right, once is enough. Because in the end, we only regret the chances we didn't take.
Barakamon is an anime full of comedy that will surprise you. I'd been looking forward to seeing the series since it came out. Who could have guessed that this anime will hold my interest? I'm always looking for a masterpiece anime to watch, but anime series nowadays lack the urgency and thematic depth to show. Barakamon, on the other hand, is a good example of the opposite.
Story 
This story is about Seishuu Handa (voiced by Daisuke Ono), a young man fullof enthusiasm for his job as a calligrapher. Because of his artistic skill, he has quite a big ego. His work is considered to be perfect since Handa has outstanding talent. Things get quite interesting when the director of an exhibition criticizes his work for lacking a personal touch and not being as great as Handa expected. This is when Handa loses his temper and delivers a rage-filled punch to the old man. As a result, Handa is sent to an island near Kyushu to cool down and take a break from his work as a calligrapher. His father has a house built on that island. As soon as he arrives at the Goto Island, he is already welcomed by a tomboyish little girl named Naru who has been staying at the house all this time. Here, Handa who had thought of himself as perfect and did not allow other people to try fix his life or do something about his temper slowly grows into fixing it by himself. Living on the island turns out to be a good lesson for Handa.


Character 

Handa is actually a good person but lacks determination as he doesn't really have a friend besides his family and one best friend who didn't expect him to be successful as a calligrapher at first. Indeed, Handa could be considered perfect since he is good-looking, wealthy, and living a dream. A lack of hardship as well as having no real friends is probably a factor as to why Handa doesn't pay attention to attitude or behavior. Handa began to trust only his own opinion and cast out others from his life. Thus, Handa has a hard time when it comes to dealing with others and finds it frustrating. As the story goes on, Handa's behavior is sometimes more immature than Naru's. Handa acts like a kid who doesn’t need help from his parents, and yet Handa becomes a real man by the end of series. Eventually, Handa's personality begins to soften and he becomes gentle to others. The island's population is small but they all act like one big family. Handa finds out that it is nice to have people to rely on which also inspires him to be a better person and a better calligrapher.


Naru, who also finds Handa quite interesting as he just arrived on the island, is slowly trying to become his close friend even though she's still a kid. The kid always hangs out around Handa and follows him every chance she gets. I also find it refreshing how villagers of all ages accept Handa without prejudice even though Hiroshi (a high school student) thinks he is just a pretty face but actually worthless. Nevertheless, kids, old men, high school students and people of every gender become close to Handa in no time. This is kind of training for Handa to achieve his dream and to improve his behavior and attitude. Since, yeah, even if you're angry, do you punch some helpless old man? It becomes quite dramatic. I even shed tears. Yes, sad tears - I cried because of the sadness that built up in me. I felt like it reflected me who didn't feel anything at first but if you really think about it, it feels just like a punch to your parent. If your parent is being punched by someone, can you still sit and watch without feeling anything? That's more than enough of a reason for me to feel guilty, I can't bear it. Well, enough of me being a crybaby and back to the main story. Handa gets into sticky situation after sticky situation with Naru, Hiroshi and the high school student girls as long as he in the island. At the end of the series, it's not only Handa who learn from his mistake, yes, I am talking about myself, too. I need to build up more attitudes myself. This is what I call learning while watching. 


Enjoyment and Overall 

I found this series' concept to be pretty amazing. It teaches you how to behave towards people who are older than you. Not like some people out there who don't give a damn over this matter. I, without a doubt, found it really interesting. I really enjoyed the series from episode one but it's all thanks to the good work of the producers. They have successfully created a good anime series. This series is also quite entertaining since I always laugh out during each episode at the characters' behavior. A good anime with a lot of creativity here. You'll feel like wanting to watch it again. Handa's mother will also play an important part later on and it's of the funniest parts. Enjoy it to your heart's content. Also make sure you have a tissue paper, too. Believe me, Barakamon is the winner of this season. Barakamon does such a good job showing both the funny and serious aspects of life. I have no regrets after watching the series. I actually found it quite fun to watch. Personally, I'm considering Barakamon to be one of my favorite shows of all time. This series is certainly outrageous anime that is more than meets the eye. Highly recommended to all anime fans.

Barakamon. Barakamon. Barakamon.
It just keeps buzzing around in my head, after watching the series in a week. 
It really surprised me. I truly did not expect an anime about writing calligraphy to be such a fun and worthwhile watch.
Story: 10
The story is quite refreshing, after so many animes being either 1) WE GOTTA SAVE THE WORLD OMG!! or 2) just plain ridiculous.
The story feels like it could really happen, and the only problem I could find was that it felt a bit hurried along. Following Handa's misadventures on the island feels natural, and very heartwarming. The ending almost brought a tear to my eye. 
Art:8\n
The art is pretty average, but the calligraphy seems to pop right off the screen. The ED in particular has very good animation, and the entire anime has pretty detailed characters and backgrounds.\n\n
Sound: 8 \n
The voices were pretty well picked, and they all deliver pretty well, without sounding strained. The OP and ED weren't my favourites, but they are pretty good, with excellent lyrics.\n\n
Characters: 10\n
The characters are very well written, and the all interact very naturally with each other. Watching Handa's development was very worthwhile, and he truly emerges a different person by the end of the anime. I truly identify with Handa, and I expect many people would too. The other characters stick well to their identities, with each character having their own lesson to impart to Handa. \n\n
Enjoyment: 10\n
This anime is one that I enjoyed thoroughly, from start to end. Sometimes the comedy feels a bit forced, but then it's quickly covered by the truly touching moments between Handa and the other characters.\n\n
Overall : 9\n
This anime is veritably one of this season's finest, and really manages to stand apart from the rest. Everyone should watch it, if they have the time. \n

"What does it mean to be yourself?".
This line pretty much summarizes what this anime is about.
First of all I would list its good points:
1) Beautiful-pure art & animation:This is one of the best animation I've seen in animes. As a slice of life anime it is pretty much an "ideal".
2)Fabulous setting and story:The story is unique yet common.It is shown in a funny way but with the truth of our true fights with our true self.People tend to forget what's important and this anime pretty much bring it in front of our eyes.
3)Lovable characters:Personally I think this is it's strongest point. Hanada-sensei as a genius-yet-lonercalligrapher who hit an old man because he bad-mouthed his calligraphy, Naru - a cheerful(too much but in a cute and funny way) kid who is the heart of this show and many more.


4)Music-OP & ED were beautifully composed and written ,totally in accordance with the anime plot.


Alright so i have pointed out some good points about it but everything has a bad side so I would also like to point them out:


1)It is a simple story.If you are not interested in life-philosophy stuff then this anime is not something you are looking for now.


2)It's a breather type of anime so if you are not looking for something refreshing you should skip it.



In the end I would like to suggest one thing that you must see this anime one time or add to your "to watch list".It is a type of manga which might motivate about life more.

So that's that.


Result:Strongly recommended.

My reviews will be entirely subjective and the last few episodes will have a big influence on the final score, they will also not outline the good and the bad points neatly, rather, they will be my thoughts on some important points.
Barakamon was an anime i had been meaning to watch since many months.
And it started out very well.After 2-3 episodes, i thought it might very well end up as a 9 for me, at the least.But sadly, it never really took off.
The initial premise itself was too silly for me to ever take seriously.I mean, Calligraphy?!No one cares about shit like that these days.Okay,not exactly shit, but it was really hard to stomach the notion that some people would dedicate their entire lives to writing neatly.


But i watch slice of life mainly for the characters and the interaction between them, and Barakamon's characters were introduced very well, so i was'nt bothered much by its premise.My favorite genre is slice of life, more specifically, comedic slice of life.And as everyone knows, though characters are always important in anime, their importance is exponentially more so in these kinds of anime.And what i felt is that they were never explored as much as they could have been here.They become pretty stale by around the 8th episode.


I am not even sure i know the protagonist after all these episodes, and that's worrying to me.He was the one who had the most screentime of all the characters, and was supposed to have grown as a person by the end, but there was never any conflict anywhere for him to make us believe so.


I was actually resigned to give this an 8 even after i was bothered by many things in it, but the 9th episode totally spoiled it for me.Since giving anything away here would be potential spoilers, let me just say that what the protagonist did was totally uncharacteristic and does'nt make any sense to a rational person.I mean *SPOILERS*no one can be that nervous and his initial calligraphy entry for the contest was far far better than his final submission.*SPOILERS*.

Also *SPOILERS*, the way his mother suddenly changes her mind in the last episode is ridiculous, that part was handled very poorly.*SPOILERS*


The art is good, but not outstanding and does'nt break any new boundaries.But i am not particular about art anyway, unless its outstanding and breaks convention or so bad that it interferes with my enjoying said anime.


The only reason it has ended up with a 7 is because i genuinely enjoyed the first 6 episodes or so, but unfortunately, it slowly descended into mediocrity after that, with a predictable plot and some cliche dialogues.


P.S- The protagonist's mother looks, at the most, 35 years old( a really attractive one at that), while his dad looks like his mothers father!For some reason, i was annoyed by these character designs.

This is a great anime for those who feel down cause it makes you feel happy.
[7/10] STORY I thought the reason he was on the island was kinda lame, like it could have been much better. I'm not saying it was crap, I just saying it need more.
[9/10]  ART The art was very good, but it wasn't the best for it's time. NGNL looked nicer even though it is older.
[10/10] SOUND I thought voice acting was incredible, I enjoyed the voice acting and the opening and ending credits. I felt the voice acting was fitting and full of emotion.
[10/10] CHARACTERS The characters werelike the icing on the cake, all the main characters were described so well and when they were sad I also felt sad with them. They're loveable characters.\n\n
[10/10] ENJOYMENT After not watching much anime any more, I jumped back in with Barakamon. After finishing it I felt light-hearted, I'm still smiling from from finishing it yesterday.\n\n
[10/10] OVERALL I loved this anime as it has brought me joy and laughter. I highly recommend this to anyone who like light-hearted anime. Thanks to my anime club at my school for showing me this amazing anime.

Barakamon is a wonderful anime, and is probably the best example of how to do a good slice of life anime.
Story: 9
Barakamon's plot revolves around the struggles of a young, but popular calligrapher, who is forced to go to a small island when he punches the head of a calligraphy exhibition. The story largely follows his path towards maturity, and his relationship with the islanders. The anime is slow and calm, and the story rarely escapes it's tendency to use a situation each episode to deliver a lesson involving tenacity and inspiration when creating something. For the most part, the story is about character interactionsand growth, so most episodes don't have anything too significant happen.


Art: 8

The art in Barakamon is great. All of the characters are fluid and expressive, and some of the scenery is gorgeous. The art style often looks similar to a painting, but isn't very different or unusual. The arts weakest point is that while some scenes are wonderful, plenty if them are pretty average, and they resort to using completely white eyes and other common anime gags a little too often, still it isn't distracting or obtrusive.


Sound: 8

The op and ed are fantastic. The soundtrack itself is good, but nothing really stands out and it can get repetitive. The sound design is about as good as a slice of life could need to be. The voice acting is all great, and no one feels out of place or awkward.


Character: 10

Easily the best part of this anime is it's characters. Almost every character gets good characterization, and no one feels particularly shallow or stereotypical. The main character gets the clearest amount of growth and depth, but a surprising amount of the side characters get plenty of screen time to grow and build their character. The changes the main character goes through are very relatable, and his path towards finding his inspiration is very fun to watch and follow.


Enjoyment: 10 

There's little to be said here other than that each episode is both funny, and intriguing. There are no moments that aren't fun and engaging.


Overall: 9 

The only real thing keeping this from being a 10 is the lack of something truly outstanding. Everything is done wonderfully, and there are no large problems or flaws in this anime. A perfect example of the absolute best a single season slice of life can be.

Barakamon is one of those anime that you cannot help but love. It's a feel-good story about a calligraphy artist who is sent to a remote island off the coast of Japan and how the character's life changed while he was there. And change it did. 
Story: 9/10 - Okay, when I first heard about this anime I wasn't exactly sure how I would enjoy it. If done wrong, it could've become boring, but the pace of the anime almost seemed fast - which is kind of funny due to the slice of life genre.
Art: 9/10 - Wonderful. The art perfectly suited the story thatwas being told. 


Sound: 9/10 - When I think of who the anime producers cast for the anime I found that I was pleasantly surprised. All of the voices suited each character down to the T. That alone made the overall rating bump up for me. Also, the great soundtrack boosted the feeling throughout the series!


Character: 10/10 - Wow! Just Wow! I don't think I've ever come across an anime where I have liked every single one of the characters! Each were so diverse and completely crazy in their own way: from the annoying little girl, to the reserved boy, to the messy but loveable teen. Everyone had their role in this anime and played it exceedingly well! Their interactions with the main character really made this story come alive.


Enjoyment: 9/10 - What can I say...enjoyment level to the max!


Overall: 9/10 - If you want a feel-good, make you smile anime...this is the one for you! With the fantastic: soundtrack, characters, and storyline; Barakamon is one for the books. One to watch when you're feeling down; or just to see whenever you feel like it! Such a fantastic series! :)

"Barakamon" is a sweet anime about what it takes to really grow and mature.
"﻿Barakamon" is a heartwarming slice of life that turned out to be very unique in that it centered around an adult finding his place in the world.  It was cute, comedic, and filled with very fun moments.
Meet Handa, Seishuu, an impulsive temperamental twenty-three year old who decided it was a good idea to punch a famous caligrapher for insulting his work. As punishment, Seishuu is sent off to a small island and forced to adapt to his new wacky neighbors, like people traveling on a tractor, unwanted visitors who never usethe front door, annoying kids using his home as a playground, etc. Can this city guy handle all the crazy hardships? Find out in this wacky island comedy full of innocence and laughter!


Daisuke Ono (Sebastian [Black Butler]) strikes again, voicing Sieshuu! Only, this character isn't the sexy butler that everyone may be aware of. Oh no. Seishuu is a wimp, a city boy through and through. Ono perfectly plays the part of this character through all of Seishuu's stutterings and panic attacks. Moving on, sweet nine year old Suzuko Hara plays the fearless, but adorable Naru. This girl doesn't even sound like she's nine. She sounds like she's a grownup who can sound like a nine year old, that's how good she is. Looking forward to more work from Hara!


In short, I loved this anime. Not a lot of animes make me laugh, but this one was filled with so many ridiculous moments, I couldn't help but laugh! The art style was nice and clear, and so very detailed! The music in the anime was sweet and filled me with this warm fuzzy feeling. The pacing was perfect, and I didn't have any questioning thoughts or worries.


You you feel like watching a simple, funny, yet sweet anime, the Barakamon is the one for you! If you're more of an action, fast paced lover, then you might not like this, but I suggest giving it a try. It is truly a cute series, and very lovable.


-


Story - 9

The story line was great, following a grown man throughout his trials and errors as a calligraphist. I got to see him grow, as well as become friends with all the odd people on the island. To my knowledge, there isn't any plot holes. This anime was very well done.


Art - 8

The art is sweet, refreshing, and very detailed. The hair has so many strands! The backgrounds are just gorgeous and radiate a glowing sunny look. The art just makes me feel happy.


Music - 9

The music was very cute and quirky, fitting the atmosphere of the anime very well.


Character - 8

The characters were very well developed. I'd like to have known more about Seishuu's family and the calligrapher he punched, but that may just be me getting picky.


Enjoyment - 8

I don't think there was an episode in which I didn't laugh. Seishuu has to win the 'Funniest Character of the Season' trophy. If there is no such thing, it needs to be made. And if he doesn't win it, then I'm flipping a few dozen tables.


Overall - 8.4

This anime was definitely one of the highlights this season. It made me happy on even the cloudiest of days, and never failed to give off that sweet and soothing feeling of fellowship and friendship.

When I first started watching an anime about a depressed artist who is constantly pestered by children as he tries to work, I admit I was skeptical. Normally I don't really care for slice of life type anime, and I find the portrayal of children in anime often distasteful. 
This anime is different. While it is not the best anime I've ever seen, it is very high on my list simply for its profundity and dedication to realism. In every scene, this anime intentionally draws realistic characters in believable situations and weaves their escapades into a thought-provoking consideration about what we value and why. Iappreciated the cultural notes as well; this anime is not westernized and viewers gain a lot of cultural richness. This anime feels like a place I could step into and find my purpose in life. I would watch again, and might force friends to watch if they had nothing better to do.

Barakamon on the surface is an anime revolving around a young adult who goes to a remote island to grow up after an altercation at a calligraphy competition. Although this plot seems limited, the plot is not what carries the show to being a truly memorable experience. Its the characters that make Barakamon. 
Barakamon has a reoccurring cast of  roughly 8 characters, each who are well developed over the show. The way each character learns, grows, and interacts is what makes this show really touching. The kids feel like kids, the adults feel like adults. Humor is used nearly flawlessly throughout the show, andthe way a normal day can be made so eventful through silly antics, and cute interactions was quite impressive. I found the way the MC changes throughout the show was really entertaining, and each of the kids was lovely. The way they hastle Sensai, and mess around is really entertaining, while they add to the growth of sensei and the town itself. 


Artwork was great, sound was simple but well utilized. 


Overall, this show is best described as fun. not to much happens, but what does is very entertaining and enjoyable. you love the cast, you love the humor, scenery, and the subtle hints about the craft of calligraphy. 


Watch Barakamon if you haven't, its a great simple show to just feel good, have fun and pass the time.

Barakamon is one of those series that best show the simplicity of life. 
The medium of anime is often populated with monsters, otherworldly creatures, special powers and overcomplicated plots (not that I'm complaining), where a lot happens fast. 
Barakamon is the opposite, true to its genre (slice of life) it follows a story where there ain't a lot of action nor progression in the plot, rather you follow the mundane life (yet highly entertaining) of Sei. 
I won't go into the plot details as I believe the synopses do a wonderful job of it but suffice to say that this is a gem of aseries. It resembles a wonderful and pure memory from a happier time in your life, like a high school field trip, or that fun weekend you spent with your parents as a child. \n\n
There is a lot of character development, as you see the lives of both Sei and the islanders merging him into the community. The high jinks of child play and a lot of care and attention that could very well be a recounting of real-life events. As even if exaggerated for comedic porpuses the interactions come as organic and real. Oh and speaking of characters, and avoiding spilling any fun to be had, beware of Naru, as she will make you smile and laugh as you haven't in a long time. Especially as she represents the essence of a 7-year-old, and even if I'm repeating myself, she is portrayed in such a pure, joyous way, that you can't help but smile.\n\n
Regarding both the cinematography, art style and sound design there isn't much to say, not that they are bad by any means but because they match the tone and spirit of the story to a T. Beautiful smooth animation, filled with comedic effects here and there that enhance the visual storytelling. Crisp naturalist sounds represent the simplicity of the Island lifestyle.\n\n
On a final note, the only thing I can say is that you deserve to watch this anime, to make yourself feel better in life because after all life is hard and we all deserve a breath of fresh air here and there.

To be honest: I hated this anime at first. 
During the first episode I found Naru to be the most annoying little brat I could think of but as the story went on I grew to like her and the other characters. I liked the main character from the start.
The story is great for a slice of life and doesn't feel forced. The characters bring you along by themselves. There are moments when it is very obvious where the scene is headed but it surprises me at other times which has a nice balance to it.
I didn't think much of the sound but when Idid notice, it was pleasant.\n\n
Overall I enjoyed it after giving it some time. If you want a quick slice of life anime to relax and laugh with I would recommend Barakamon.

The cliche of "city slicker goes to a rural town, struggles as a fish out of water, before finally maturing to deal with their inner troubles" has been done many times. In Barakamon we have a calligrapher who goes to a rural town in Japan to seek redemption and gain a new insight into his life and career. While the main plot goes the same way as you'd expect the cliche would, it is still a heartwarming gem that exceeds expectations.
The most interesting part of Barakamon is its cast. While many may focus on Naru, the loud and energetic child who is the main driverfor getting Handa out of his shell, the rest of the cast play their part. They are all interesting in their own way without falling into the hyper-exaggerated character tropes usually seen in anime. Hence, Barakamon creates a town full of fun personalities that you wish you could be a part of. 


Speaking of tropes, the other main trope Barakamon avoids is having each episode focus on a specific character's problem, where Handa gets involved and solves the problem which helps him learn more about himself. Instead this show follows regular life in a country town. The largest obstacles the characters face are things like fixing a bath boiler. There is minimal drama here until the climax where Handa needs to face his demons.


Barakamon is an anime with plenty of comedic moments, great characters and an entertaining, yet simple story. If you like a fun slice of life, watch this.

Stories about people chasing their dreams will always be popular because of how addictive and inspiring they are. Anime doesn't stand aside, presenting us a large variety of works telling about how important it is to have a dream of your life, how it gives you energy, how it makes you whole. From multiple sports animes to Bakuman to Uchuu Kyoudai, hell, to even Berserk at some point, there are literally tons of them, in any genre, you name it. 
And then there's Barakamon doing basically the same thing but with one subtle nuance which make it really stand out for me.
So, what's the storyabout? Seishuu Handa, our protagonist, is a calligrapher. Yes, it's a person who draws (writes?) hieroglyphs for a living, which sounds kinda odd for a westerner like me, but okay. One day, he participated in an exhibition (yes, they have those), where an elderly critic (and those too) saw his work and... didn't really like it, to say the least. Handa, having heard all that, lost his temper and punched the critic in the face. The problem is, in the artworld, you don't' punch critics in the faces, you just don't. Even if you really want to. Especially the elderly ones. But what's done is done, so Handa's professional future suddenly started looking very grim. His father, trying to somehow sort the situation out, decided to send Handa to a small distant island with a lonesome little village on it, so that he would lay low for a while and hope the dust eventually settles down. Handa isn't ecstatic about this, but realizes he can use it to his advantage, so he goes to the island with a single intent: be alone and work, work, work. But as it often happens, things go wrong pretty quickly. Or do they?..


So yeah, it's that old story about how he meets a bunch of nice people, how he tries to avoid them but they eventually grow on him, how he becomes a part of this small village's community, blah-blah-blah, all that old stuff. I think, it's not correct to say that the story is not Barakamon's strong point, but rather that the story is not something it bets on. It doesn't have a complex story not because it cannot, but because it doesn't really need it to convey what it wants to convey.


From a technical standpoint Barakamon surprisingly looks better... well, it may be a weird thing to say, but it looks better than it has to. I mean, come on, it's a simple little story, it's usually not expected to look more than just "okay". Nevertheless, it does: the artworks and the sound is actually really-really decent, and the opening holds a spot in my top-10 favourites. Not something breathtaking, but it's nice to see this much effort and soul put into a seemingly small work. And that diligence shows in everything, creating a very special atmosphere of tranquility and warmth.


Again, there are a lot of animes, and who knows how many other media, telling us how important it is to go after your dreams. Barakamon, on the other hand, adds a remark not said aloud by many: don't forget to live on the way. Try and find joy in simple things as well. Don't just mindlessly pursue your goal like a robot, instead make a stop once in a while to look around, raise your head and see the sky and stars above. Yes, the dream of your life is surely important, but your life has so much more to it. And that, I'd say, is a thought that deserves to be spoken far more often.

Inspiration comes in nature (Barakamon) 
After viewing the non non biyori I was impressed by the atmosphere serene village life, so Barakamon waited impatiently. And not in vain! 
Needless anime easy enough story: a young calligrapher Handa could not contain their emotions at the criticism of his paintings and struck his master, for it was sent for re-education (looking for inspiration) to another island. Handa was driving with only one thought - to work and write. But the island has decided differently ... 
Of stale, freak only in pictures and your goal Handa began to turn into a man. And all thanks to a littlerestless girl Naru and her friends. I admit, at first I myself did not love her recklessness and importunity, but after a couple of episodes I was on her wave :) Collect beetles, climb mountains, fish, watch the sunset - at any time, just call me :) \n
After watching such anime know how important it is to live. Do not walk like a robot for the purpose, and to look around, just raise your eyes and see the stars. Blindly following the pre-planned purpose, we often forget to enjoy the little things - the smiles of friends, conversations with neighbors, privacy or unexpected party. We become too stiff and just awaken their child. As soon as you stop to think linearly and relax instantly find your style inspiration. \n
This anime need to feel the feelings that arise when viewing, remember and keep in my heart.\n\n
P.S. sorry, original text in russian was google translated because of amateur knowledge of english. I'm improving my english now.

I feel like if there wasn't so much hype about this anime while it was running, it would definitely be underestimated. By the cover art, the title, and the plot, you wouldn't think of this anime to be very good. However, that is not the case.
Usually titles and plots will turn me away from an anime, but from the very first episode, you will be automatically drawn to the charm and charisma of each character. This is one of those special anime that doesn't need fighting, supernatural beings, or an over-hyped fandom to make it great.
Basically, don't let the fact that this anime is abouta calligrapher turn you away from it. Without a doubt, you will enjoy this anime in some aspect whether it's from the humor, character development, excitement, friendship, or just a little bit of it all.

There’s a question I get posed with every once in a while when someone asks me about my anime preferences: “Why slice of life?” This question stumps me for a bit; I get lost in my thoughts, try to form an explanation that sounds quasi-intelligent, and after a minute of awkward silence and blank stares, I come to a conclusion that gratifies my conscience, but leads to anger or confusion:
“Why not?”
Barakamon is an excellent example of why I adore the slice of life genre not only because it embodies the characteristics that make the genre so enjoyable and accessible to a wide audience, but itsimultaneously dissuades common, negative stereotypes with its simplicity in execution. 


Handa Seishuu is a bit of a unique personality. As a famous calligrapher whose progress in life has been closely monitored by those around him, it’s pretty safe to say that all of the stress that surrounds him would be enough to bring any normal individual to his knees. Needless to say, Seishuu’s no superhuman, so what is ultimately expected happens: he caves – big time. After KO punching a well-known calligraphy critic for scrutinizing his work as lifeless, Seishuu’s friend, Kawafuji, and his father, Seimei, send him to a small island to collect his thoughts and chill the heck out.


At this point, it sounds like the “story” will carry out predictably and his path to redemption is all but guaranteed, as dictated by the storytelling gods. The beauty of Barakamon, though, is that is (almost) exactly what happens. However, if such a conclusion seems that inevitable, why does Barakamon still stand out not only when compared to other slice of life anime, but to other anime in general?


We begin the complicated path towards that answer with an innocent little creature, Kotoishi Naru, whose personality is indicative of both the atmosphere and direction of Barakamon’s “story.” In most slice-of-life narratives, little thought is given to a cohesive storyline; in fact, the nature of these series is character-driven. Thus, in order to create a strong slice of life anime, strong characters are necessary. Let’s stop here for a second and discuss the following question: what does it mean to be a “strong” character in slice of life? Must a character encounter and conquer conflict? Does she need to express her inner thoughts through philosophical introspection? Will these questions ever lead us to an answer?


Chances are they won’t, but believe it or not, the answer is much simpler than the questions suggest. Taking a page out of Naru’s book, it just has to be “gobs of fun,” and that is exactly what all of the characters in Barakamon, led by Naru, provide for the audience. Barakamon’s cast embodies the very definition of character: expressive, diverse, human. Simple traits – Naru’s bubbliness or Hiroshi’s indifference – complement each other while building unique personas that help make the cast such a memorable one. However, for those who blindly characterize character depth solely through loose definitions of “development”, “maturity”, or some cryptic hodgepodge of esoteric script-writing, Barakamon humbly fulfills this plate with an expected, yet coherent tale of Seishuu’s path to what most people in their mid-twenties search for: a role in life. 


With the unbounded potential of anime as a story-telling medium, typically what one would expect is a flashy and dramatic journey of self-realization that culminates with our glorious protagonist coming to peace with his past demons and becoming an entirely new person. 


Barakamon says to hell with that. 


Instead, the show leisurely builds Seishuu’s character through a series of insignificant, comedic moments dashed with tidbits of wisdom. Nothing glorious here, but how Seishuu comes in terms with his past and his quarter-life crisis is beautiful in its grounding in reality. There is no defining moment, no moment of Nirvana, and no deliberate pacing. In fact, there are times where Seishuu “develops” as a person quickly, only to take two steps back. However, it is in this awkward, unpredictable growth where we see Barakamon’s undeniable ability to tell a story so familiar and relatable, yet also send a message while entertaining with ease. 


And boy does it send a message. From catching beetles under the scorching summer sun to enjoying an archetypal seasonal festival, Barakamon effortlessly conveys to the audience its genuine philosophy of life as a thin veneer over the bulk of its content, which consists of everyday goings, short gags, and the occasional serious moment. It proceeds throughout its twelve entertaining episodes without changing its formula and holding true its aforementioned identity.


Barakamon’s character design and animation are both pretty standard for 2014. Unlike contemporary anime, there isn’t too much overt sexualization, which is always a breath of fresh air. Backgrounds have a soft color palette making the visual experience more soothing. Music is a definite plus in Barakamon. From a strong opening and ending combination to a soundtrack that always seems to play the right track at the right time, the show satisfied all basic visual and audial desires.


“What does it mean to be yourself?” This is the simple question Barakamon explores without needing to spell it out. Instead, with its vibrant cast and simple story structure, Barakamon is able to stand out from the crowd, and I believe it is perhaps one of the best, and definitely the most sincere anime I have had the pleasure to enjoy in 2014.

BARAKAMON, the anime that restored my faith for anime after a hiatus of watching shit animes and severe mental defecation. Many thanks to my friend, Samual for recommending this anime to me after that previous disappointing piece of shit. Thank you for your kindness, your enduring understanding, and for being the wonderful SJW that you are. 
Before I begin my review, I'd like to give a big shoutout to our boy Karl on getting D5 in league of legends as we look forward to welcoming him in P1 next season. Your hardwork and dedication is a true testament to your determination, and will live onin that border of yours for the next 400 days. 


Now onto the review.


Barakamon taught me that an anime can be good, while being completely and utterly uneventful. Now, I know what you're thinking. 'But hey PressurizedTurd, how can an anime be both unsubstantial and good?' Well, I'm glad you asked cuz that's where you're wrong dear boy!!! When did I say Barakamon is unsubstantial? In fact I daresay Barakamon is filled with as much substance as the testosterone in my ball sack after listening to Flo Rida for it filled my soul with the essence of poetry. It was free flowing, rhythmic, with the occasional UMPH to give me that jump start to my emotions. I've been off the needle for a few years now and let me just preach to you fools that this anime revitalized me with that same rush without the STDs. Thank you Kinema Citrus for producing this poetic sensation and keeping me off the streets. 


The greatness of this anime is comparable to that of Jane Eyre. Have you ever read Jane Eyre? That subtle gentleness of the morning breeze, describing a delicate blade of grass in 20 pages is something I cannot possibly forget in this lifetime or the next. Besides the obvious beauty of its descriptive description, it made me want to claw my eyes out because Jane Eyre was such a basic whore and LITERALLY described a blade of grass for 20 pages. But in Barakamon we have Naru, who came in like a wrecking ball at juuuuuust the right moments to prevent the narrative from plunging into a Ed Sheehan song. This is the decisive difference between this animated masterpiece and that literary shit they call Jane Eyre.


Barakamon is an anime best seen in the confines of solidarity while thinking about life. It's definitely not like DxD or other 'bro' animes that you watch with your homies. Personally, I drank citrus black tea and sought answers to the many questions of life and to my surprise, it worked. What is life? What is light? Did Brett Kavanaugh rape Christine Ford? The answers came pouring in like a ray of hope, that same voice of reason that we saw in Interstellar. By watching Barakamon, I found the 5th element, that final puzzle piece to end my lifelong trek in seeking answers. 


Before I get side tracked let me explain my review. Barakamon is a balanced anime where no one area overshines the other. Which is why my scores represent the same score x6. But as I've phrased previously, Barakamon was a great anime that provided me answers to life and its spiritual meanings. During a period when tinder was taking over my life, it taught me that all girls are sluts and through my love for Hina, I've received my calling to uninstall and wait till a real world Hina would come into my life. I have no doubt that this anime can help realize your calling as well. 


Goober gobble thank you Barakamon.

This will be my first review ever on this site. I know that this might be a bit amateur(-ish) but please bare with me and hopefully this can give you all new comers some insights into this anime.
After all new waves of fantasy animes, blood, gore, flashy colors etc. I thought to myself.
"Well...I guess that's it. I think, I see everything"
I then laid back on my chair when I saw a picture of this anime. Its the picture of a man wearing all-blue walking with a kid beside him
"Great another slice of life anime...I will just give it a try" Next thing I know, Ifinished the entire series and later on would finish the manga.


I would like to compare this anime to a cup of hot chocolate on a cold winter night. It made my heart grew 3 sizes as with the grinch during Christmas and help me to reignite my love for this genre once again.


Story 9/10:

Again the selling point of this anime is its pure slice of life style of story telling, Exploring the life of a Junon-boy(hehe) living life in a small town. The hook(some might agree with me) was at the last scene on episode 1. The scene hits home due to my personal experience as a city boy, who loves to go visit my grandparents once in awhile. The music to accompanies it made the scene more memorable and warmy feeling.


Art 8/10:

I know I know I put 8 there. Yes the character have their difference in styles and over the art is great with fluid animation...with a little of rough here and there but hey its still very good.


Sound 9/10:

If you read my story part, you'll know that the music in this anime really compliment the scene. From the warm, fuzziness in the first episode to the random encounter of comedy that is sprinkling throughout the show. The music really gives you the feeling of "small town" vibes. And Oh My Glory the opening...the damn OPENING! I cant get this song out of my head(in a good way of course) and also a very warm and fuzzy ending is very appreciated.


Character 9/10:

AH yes this is gonna be fun. The character in this anime are full of colors and unique in their own ways. We have Handa-sensei; A quick temper, calligrapher as a main character he's...lets say...different and with time he develops from hard headed to slightly cool temper with a bit of heat in there. The supporting case are also interesting; Tamako with her secrets of being a fujoshi, Miwa's boyish character, Kawafuji with his comedy with Handa and my favorite character naru with her fun going personalities that really make me want to have her as my child((Police please don't arrest me))


Enjoyment 10/10:

Heck yes I enjoyed the show and hopefully the new comers will too. From start to finish you will never be disappointed. 


Overall 9/10:

As I said from the beginning;Barakamon is like a Hot chocolate during Winter. it warms your heart, made you feel good about your life, made me remember my pass((personal)) and after this anime on, you'll feel refresh and encourage to go and dive again into the anime world. 


Thank you for reading this review and hopefully you will love this show as much or even much more than I do.

Let me preface the review by saying I detest children in anime because they are either extremely obnoxious and/or they are designed and shown as overly cute to obviously manipulate the viewers emotions. I also hate tsundere characters because of how irritating and violent they are towards other characters turning them into crappy one note characters.
Barakamon is perhaps one of the rarest shows that not only manages to circumvent it but makes a person like me, who hates annoying kids and tsunderes in anime, fall in love with the show.
It centers on protagonist Seishuu Handa, a 23 year old genius calligrapher who gets exiled tothe countryside due to an unfortunate incident. He has always been absorbed in his work and competitions to such a degree that his social life is 0 with him having only one friend. He is that handsome guy you wonder about why he doesn't have a relationship with anything other than his work. Now Handa is a tsundere but his portrayal goes beyond the typical violent cliche that plagues anime/manga nowadays. He's tsundere in all the right ways and this makes his reactions and expressions even more fun to watch.


The deuteragonist of the show, Naru, a 7 year old tomboy is remarkable in herself because her character never manipulates the viewer into feeling any of the typical emotions related to one-note kids in anime. She helps Seishuu see a world beyond calligraphy and he creates a bond with her that alleviates her loneliness in a way even the villagers cannot.


The supporting cast is fun as well so in the interest on not spoiling anything, I'll just say enjoy them as and when Seishuu meets them. 


The show is pure slice of life. Don't expect anything else from it - drama, romance, action etc are not there and the show is all the more better for it.


I just want to tell everyone to watch this show now. It has hidden life lessons that don't get beaten over your head and you go on a memorable and very charming journey with the most unlikeliest pair of characters in a long, long time.

I liked this show. It was a good comedy in it's own right, and had a little more serious undertone on it. This was bought together with a good setting and great characters. Let's get this review started. I should seeming as I started this like 4 months ago!
*MINOR SPOILERS*
We follow the story of a Seishuu Handa, a calligraphy artist who was forced as a kid to practice calligraphy day and night until we come to present time, where the 20-ish Handa is trying to find his own style. He presents a piece of work to a Director of an Art Group who dissaproves. Handais naturally annoyed and assaults the director. He is punished by being banished to an island - an extreme version of "go to your room". Ensue the comedy. - Story, 7


Art and Sound - Again, as said in many of reviews, the art follows a very post-2000 style, clean and nice on the eyes but nothing special. What is nice is it's set on an island, presumably not far from Tokyo (where Handa grew up and where he submitted his art too the previously mentioned Art Group), in summertime, so got a very summer holidays feel to it, ironically like the island from animal crossing new leaf. On 3DS. You should play it. NOW. Only 29.99... Sorry, sound. Sound is nothing special, the music/OST anyway, BUT this is why I love anime comedy, the Japanese know how to use sound to amplify comedy. For example, Handa comes into a situation where he bolts upright because he's in a stressful situation, and as he bolts up the sound of a xylophone being like run down, can't think how to explain it, but yeah, it really makes it that more funnier. 7/7.


Character - there's a good cast number, but I'll run down the main ones. I think I've covered Handa enough, he's nothing more than your average protagonist really, an artist just trying to find himself while having to deal with the distractions of middle school teens, people living in a rural, no-electric community, and 7 year-olds. Speaking of which,

Naru Kotoishi - This little girl is supposed to be the other protagonist I guess, the one who has the most interaction with Handa. I mean, I guess she's cute (I dunno imo, she's kinda.. Woah :P ) but I just found her annoying. I guess that's true to a 7 year old who's like massively hyper but still, who I would've preffered to take Naru's place...

Hina Kubota - Naru's best friend. Now Hina is CUTE. She doesn't really perform much of a role other than just be part of the 7 year olds who are a distraction to Handa but my God, if me or my friends have kids, I pray to whatever being there is that, if the baby is a girl, she turns out like Hina, So goddamn cute.

Miwa Yamamura - One of the middles choolers, along with Tamako Arai. They're kinda like Naru, only less annoying because there, like, double her age or older. Nice little character interaction is when Handa helps them out with a calligraphy assignment, but I'll leave it to you how you judge these characters if you decide to pick this up. Personally, 8 (think the 8 is mainly for Hina haha).


So, overall, yeah, I'd say this is worth a watch, but I suppose I'd say pick up any anime comedy because there isn't really anything else that sets this apart from any other good quality comedy. I mainly picked this up because I saw this on a streaming website and my mind is instinctively drawn to anything that looks like Pokemon. One thing, and the thing I will end on, is the fact this anime, the deep thing I was talking about in the beginning, is the fact that you should draw inspiration from going out of your comfort zone (Handa is a shut-in to begin with) and this is shown through him doing a calligraphy drawing when looking up at the night sky. I liked that, drawing inspiration from being out your comfort zone and embracing our beautiful world. And with that, I leave a reccomendation of Sayonar Zetsubi Sensei (think that's right) and another reccomendation to take a walk outside now, or a visit to the subreddit earth porn. Either will do. (Show gets a good 7).

Not recommended to people who prefer their anime plot-heavy and fantastical.
Recommended to those who need a little pick-me-up and are fond or, at the very least, not averse to well-crafted, light-hearted slice of life stories.
Story: 8
Barakamon was definitely a pleasant wonder to behold. It has the subtlety and sincerity that the some of the flashier shows lack. While it might not have a rigid, overarching plot, the main character has enough internal, and external, motivation to move the story forward and serve as a central point from which we can view and watch the other characters interact. The episodes are simply made up of momentsin the village with the similar theme of helping the MC grow. Nothing feels forced or contrived, everything in the village has a low-key natural charm to it. 


The scenes are made even more charming and distinctive by the cultural references and integrations. We learn a bit about not just the differences between country and city life--both in language and tradition--but calligraphy as well. I'm definitely no expert in the latter, but even I was able to appreciate the artistry it required.


Another notable thing about the anime is that many of it scenes usually have several interactions going on at any given time, which in my opinion is one of its strong suits. For example, while the MC and his friend are talking, the kids are usually running around in the background or trying to participate. Not only is it fun trying to take in and make sense of everything that's going on, this also lends an air of cohesion and authenticity to the scene. It portrays the chaos and random connections inherent in our usual everyday interactions.


The premise revolves around the seemingly warring conditions and expectations of youth and adulthood. It shows this through the MC's struggles to move past all the things he was taught to value as a kid that allowed him to excel in his field, and to enter the terrifying world of adults, where he is once again a beginner and must recreate and remaster himself. This disconnect is further reinforced by the introduction of his much younger rival who mirrors how the MC used to be. The tensions in the story aren't melodramatic or all that apparent. But that's precisely why the execution is so effective. It doesn't seem like a conflict that's imposed, it's one that naturally arises from the characters themselves and is exhibited in their actions and decisions. 


Art and Sound: 8

There is nothing spectacular about the art, but its simplicity complements the laid-back and relaxing tone of the story. The sound, too, complements all the other elements. The songs are light and carefree, and the voices match the characters' personalities pretty well. Naru's in particular is energetic without being annoying and is equal parts childlike and comforting. 



Characters: 9

The characters are well-constructed and often display characteristics that makes the bigger picture even more humorous and diverse. You have the village chief and his wife who regularly cook for the MC, the teacher who doesn't look like a teacher and always smokes, the adorably bratty children who have no trouble looking for insects to give to their friend for her birthday, the rival who both idolizes and tries to challenge the MC, the pseudo-gangster dad who sells liquor and values individuality, the teenage girl who dreams of writing manga and is unwillingly fascinated by male-male intimacy. They all bounce of off each other in ways that allow us to get to know them more through the situations they are in and the people around them. The kids refreshingly act like kids, with all the cut and dried honesty and innocent wisdom that characterize childhood, and the adults are convincingly complex, and confused, and learned in that way that time and experience teaches. 


Through the MC's growth, we are able to see the ways these different people affect him and the many realizations they inspire. But the anime also shows that growth isn't a linear, black and white process. It involves progressing sometimes in sudden spurts, other times in small increments, and includes the occasional regressions. It's not about erasing the people we've been until that point or totally discounting our existence to replace it with a better version of us. It's about accepting that we change as we grow older, that life continuously expects us to grow and adapt the further along we get. It's about adding to who we already are, and learning from our consistently changing realities time and time again.


The highlight of the anime, I think, is the relationship between the MC and Naru, the precocious child who always seems to be around him and knows everyone in the village. There is something so refreshing and hopeful about the way these two fill the spaces and absences in each other's life. 


Enjoyment: 10

I thoroughly enjoyed Barakamon. It makes me believe in the exciting, renewing power of new friends and experiences.
