"Staying in a city filled with noisy cars in the streets filled with people can be really frustrating and maybe you can't think straight and feel inspired. But hey, I have an idea, how 'bout you go to the Island filled with silence and joy and you'll going to meet so many people in a little town? There, you can get relaxed and comfy as they treat you as a very important person. But in return, you must give them back in return to their hospitality to you. And it might give you some lessons as you get back. How's that?" - Me thinking wheneverI missed my province


Barakamon is definitely an anime filled with happiness and laughter throughout the series. So here's my further review on this anime.


The Story is very simplistic as it explains about a man from Tokyo who wants to win in a calligraphy contests wants to take a breathing in an Island after he did something unpleasant to the director of the contest after the director saying something offensive, for him, about his work and joining the contest in a losing effort. But even though it's simplistic due to it's genre as a Slice of life, I never get bored on how this anime delivers though. The anime is filled with lessons that you might learned from here, like Cooperation to both strangers or not and being friendly, and do something in return for those people that gave you something to please. Also, the pacing of the anime is great and the anime is very entertaining that it will keep you smile and laughing as you watch this anime. The pacing is great also from start to finish. I didn't see anything rushed. For the ending, I'd say it is also good as well. It really  did deserve this anime a well end. But, hopefully this is not the end though because I fell in love with this anime. Also, I was expecting a romance here due to some characters here in the series was asking about Handa's lovelife, but the story only flows in a Comedy and slice of life. Nothing else. Kind of disappointed though. But it still a great story without it nonetheless.


As for the Characters in the story, let me put it this way. let's just say you are a person from the city and the people from a small town in a province took notice of you. And they also know you, but in a good reputation. So, in order to give you a big warm welcome to the town that you've being visiting in, they give you something to eat and gave you a warm smile as you try to know them better. But in return, you must give cooperation as well so that they will treat you that you're one of them. So... that's how I describe these characters here in Barakamon. It's hard to explain them one-by-one though (and I'm not lazy) so I just explain this instead to avoid any spoilers.


Now for minors, the art is truly remarkable though due to it's scenes, like the sunsets and the stars in the sky, and the artform of this anime is good. I thought it's from Kyoto Animation though... But for a second though, I just realize that it's not from them. But they have some similarities though, especially the scenery of the whole place where Handa, the protagonist, is currently visiting in, and the characters's artforms too... Reminds me of K-On! though.


Now for the Sound, I'd say both OP and ED are sound remarkably entertaining. Also, this is the second time I'd heard NoisyCell for the ED of this anime. The first ED I've heard from them is on MadHouse's "Death Parade". And it is kind of emotional tone rather than the OP though. But both are great though, it's not that catchy for those who aren't love rock songs. But, it's great nonetheless. For the seryuus, at first, I thought it was Rie Kugimiya who voiced Naru because I noticed due to their accents. But as I took a little bit of research, surprisingly, it was voiced by a young girl (not woman). So, it's kind of cute to hear her voice and I would like to hear her again in the future. As for the other seiryuus, there' no doubt that there's no problem here to say the least.


Overall, I should say, this anime is a brilliant work, no doubt. I really should thank to my friend who shared this anime and I really love to watch this anime. No doubt, this anime should stay around the top 100, and even though it's not too long if there's something that needs to replaced, I'll just say that this anime, again, is brilliant. I've learned a lot of this anime, and it was a jolly good show indeed. A Jolly good show...

As years go by you realize that there are stories and things in general that are worth seeing, hearing, experiencing, etc. over and over again… not because we forgot their type, or we need it like we were deprived of some nutrient or something like that, they deserve to persevere because, well… they make us smile every time.
That’s why a story of a “city boy” in the countryside makes its way to comedy yet again… and into our very core I might add.
Barakamon is… well described in the phrase you just read, up there see?  it’s still visible, and there’s really nothing more toadd plot wise, the story isn’t new, neither are the characters, wacky smiley happy characters meant to bring a smile to your face with situations sometimes overreacted and occasionally exaggerated, filled with funny faces and many of the good ol’ anime comedy staples.


So here’s the twist…


The protagonist happens to be a calligraphy writer, one of the most unique things of Japanese culture, they just do that… writing, at least to us regular folk, but see to them there’s a catch that lies in the nature of Japanese (and Chinese) character writing, an added value so personal, so culturally based, so full of layers that it might as well fall onto the category of “things people don’t care”… like art appraising, or philosophy (it's my major so I know something of people telling me “I don’t care”).


If I was to make an explanation about my take on calligraphy it would have to be that calligraphy in the Chinese way adds a layer of content to writing, since the symbols don’t necessarily represent that which the common code might suggest, is like when we westerners write poetry, we except our code to hold an special meaning trough particular interpretations, but in the case of Chinese writing the characters are themselves home to representation, since the code indented in them is not as strict as ours (or as we like it to be).


So, it is kinda of a curious kind of glue to this whole series isn’t it? I mean calligraphy appraising (or appreciation) it’s something that probably goes beyond us regular anime viewers… so why is it there? 


The contrast then isn’t really between city and countryside, it’s between the overwhelming weight of dedicating your life to such a complex thing as calligraphy against dedicating your life to the, due to a lack of a less worn out expression, the simple things. In the end the comedy is not barely physical or based on the bare contrast of lifestyles or life choices, but it lays its foundations in other difference, the one that lays between the shadow of the ghost of complex human understanding, the one that goes from the complexities of rationality and/or “common sense” such as trying to appraise calligraphy can be and beyond, and other so different kind of complexity… the complexity (or lack thereof) of happiness and simple human emotions… not that the physical setting has nothing to do with it, on the contrary, it’s the perfect place for this context to develop.


Good ol’ fun…


You may think it’s not there, this such rich and complex contrast, but that’s the magic of it, you live it, laugh at it, and enjoy it, even if you’re not aware of it, see that’s one of many of the great abilities of our human consciousness, working without us knowing, so sometime in the future up the long road of life you may look back to such moments and thoughts and realize the fulfilling greatness that they provided you, all while wearing the most innocent of disguises, or codes if you want to keep the nomenclature.

In the end Barakamon is a beautifully achieved comedy, that unlike others, takes a little sweet time to activate your brain, just enough to not only give the overall series comedic content an awesome background but also make the whole journey such more worthwhile and fulfilling than a regular unassuming comedy.. Even if you do not care enough to realize it.


Or maybe you can just laugh it out and get really happy whit it… because happiness is that kind of thing that we need to do over and over and over again, not because we need it… well you get the point.

After seeing the first episode, I honestly thought that I'd brush off and drop this anime. 
It's a slice of life anime about a young calligrapher who was forced to move to an island after he punched an art director who was critiquing his work. Throughout his stay, he slowly got to know the villagers and he was able to learn a lot of things from them. 
It doesn't have a complicated plot, the character development is not dramatic. There's no magic, epic battle scenes or romantic love story. Each episode does not have an intriguing mystery and there wasn't even a cliffhanger, but forsome reason, I had the urge to watch the next episode just so I can see Handa-sensei and the villagers live their everyday lives.


If I can describe Barakamon in one statement, it would be a "really laid back and charming show".

Oh hi there, just know that i'm writing this while waiting for my flight to an island with beautiful scenery and life-changer villagers, because that's how much Barakamon affected me. (Sorry if this review is mehh, but i'm trying to avoid giving any spoilers.) 
"You won't see any opportunities from below if you keep looking above your head all the time"
"Once you carve your path, all that's left is to walk it."
Sometimes, life isn't always the way you want it to be, and that's what makes life worth living. Watching this series, i cannot stop thinking about the beautiful hidden messages that lie within everyepisode. Slice-of-life anime has always been my favorite, and Barakamon, you're gonna stay in my list for a long period of time big boy. 


Punching the calligraphy  director - being sent to an island by his father - coping with the different lifestyle than in Tokyo. Pretty much the whole summary of Barakamon. Simple right ? That simplicity is what makes the whole story so interesting to watch. When i watch any anime, i don't really like to finish all the episodes in one day because i feel that, the longer time it takes for me to finish a series, the more connection i feel with the characters, simply because i look forward to it. ( yes, even though there are just 12 episodes. i know i'm a little weird). 


Handa is a very lovable character. He feels so low about everything except when it comes to writing calligraphy that he felt the need to punch an old director for criticizing his work, (not very lovable now doesn't he), but he started to show his true bright color throughout the series especially after meeting Naru, Hina, Tamako, Miwa and Hiro, and you know what, i love this guy. Despite his serious looking face, he has deep thoughts about everything, wisdom quotes that he said to himself, leaving him utterly embarrassed after noticing that he was heard by Naru and others.


There are times when i just want to curl up in bed, in awe of everything that happened, and sometimes i laugh at the stupid jokes, not because i think they're funny, but because of how much i can relate to those. (They are funny actually) And nope, not a single tear was shed, but i do feel my heart fluttered with happiness and other kind of feels i cannot explain, i'm not too good with words, but have you ever felt happy over small little things and everything is just great, yeah, that kind of feels. 


If you're looking for a feel good, heartwarming, inspiring anime, give it a try. 


I can't help but smile when watching the entire series. The OP and ED are so good i didn't skip any of them during those short but sweet 12 long episodes.

Season 2 ? Yes please ! And there goes my informal review. 


oops, they're already announcing my flight. Ja ne !

Barakamon is an anime series that shows you the daily lives of islanders in Japan where a city boy goes through a tough adventure. It's not your typical comedy anime, Barakamon is actually quite different compared to other anime comedies. It really shows you how big the diffrences are between cities and islands.
Story: 7. The story isn't so exciting but it's not a big deal because it's the characters that really make the whole thing into a succes.
Art: 10. Well, it's a modern and new anime made in 2014 so the art is very nice and "fresh", and by this I mean both the animationand the charactar/anime design.


Sound: 8. It doesn't really contain much soundtracks and music, but I think it's good enough for only being a 12 episode long anime. The voice actors really did a great job making the anime sound realistic, with focus on the kids voices in the anime that actually are acted by kids around the same age. Compared to other "anime kid characters" it's usually adults acting them and it doesn't sound so good and realistic.


Character: 10. The characters are the best thing in Barakamon. They are the sucess of the series making it into something unique. You'll see it yourself while watching it, I don't really want to "spoil" the best thing.


Enjoyment: 9. Barakamon is enjoyable because of it's outstanding comedy and characters, that's all I can say.


Overall: 9. Barakamon is as I have written before a unique and different comedy series that is worthy of watching. The only reason I won't give it a 10 is just since the story isn't so exciting and could've been better I guess.. But it's no big deal as I mentioned before because the real focus is on the characters.

It's really hard to find an anime that will make you laugh and feel warm inside. And Barakamon is just one of those rare treasures you'll find out there.
Story 7/10
The story is simple, and not it's strong point I'll admit. But it's what they make out of the story that makes it so enjoyable. Every episode has at least one moment where you either laugh, smile, or blow out a little more air out of your nose than you normally do ;) The producers and directors did everything right (so far) with this anime. The story is simple at first, but later it actually doesseem to get a little deeper and devulges into the importance of friendship and togetherness.


Characters 9.5678/10

The characters are definitely the strong point of the show. Every character is extremely likeable and very realistic. There's the otaku fujoshi girl, the tomboy, the energetic little girl, the shy little girl, the average achieving yet easygoing boy, and of course, your hardworking modern day city boy (or adult, whatever you wanna call Handa) Everything about the characters and their interactions just make the show 100% better. 


OST 8/10

At first I didn't really think much of the music since I didn't fully grasp the story throughout the first half of the first episode. But I soon realized what it was really about. And once the first episode ended it made me feel just truly happy and warm. Not many anime shows do that for me, or anyone I'm guessing. Once the episode ended, the ending song totally complimented the entire atmosphere. If I had to pick the most memorable track, it would be the ending; Innocence by Noisycell. It's one of those few anime songs where you don't need the actual anime [footage] to enjoy. The opening is good too. I would say the OST is average overall though.


Animation 9.678/10 

Since it is 2014, of course the animation is amazing. The animators really know how to set the happy, warm summer mood and you can tell every background is done with real care and hardwork put into it. It's actually quite stunning if you pay close attention and watch in HD.


Overall, Barakamon is a really enjoyable and heartwarming show. I'm a little bias towards this because I value the same qualities this show depicts; friendship & togetherness. If you need a break from the serious animes or just wanna laugh and smile, this is definitely the anime for you.

*This review is based on the anime series, Barakamon.
Barakamon/ ばらかもん , 12 episodes a 20 minutes, aired from July to September 2014 ; Comedy, Slife of Life ; licensed by FUNimation
Barakamon isnt your generic anime. This show may be considered something simple, non special - but thats exactly what makes it awesome. There are no battles, no magic, no harems, no romance - this is pure Slice of Life, and its awesome.
Story: 9/10
The story is something very unique. How many shows have you seen which center about calligraphy? None, of course. Barakamon tells the story of Handa, a young calligrapher who spends his days ona rural island, preparing for an upcoming exhibition. He meets new people, friends and situations and grows thanks to them. Well executed and every new episode feels new and fresh, and adds unforced and natural comedy.


Art: 10/10

Even for a relatively modern show, Barakamon's art style is more than impressive. Facial expressions and movements are done exquisitely, the calligraphy and some scenes are just perfect. Couldn't give anything else than a 10 here.


Sound: 9/10

The OP is very fitting, adds to the show's atmosphere. Non generic and something fresh, I've listened to the whole thing every episode. ED isnt as great but still good. Voices are very fitting and manage to show the difference of the islands accent and speaking style, even for a person who doesnt speak japanese. Background music is good too.


Character: 10/10

One of the key points where this shows excels. There isnt a single character who isn't unique and likeable. There arent the known dere-character styles, every single person is special and grows through the episodes, especially the MC. The comedy is also great and in synchro with the personalities.


Enjoyment: 9/10

This show is very calm and plain. It has great comedy and shows the becoming of a real adult and the struggles of hard workers. Every episodes feels fresh and brings something new, be it storywise, comedywise or characterwise. Very enjoyable. I personally wouldn't have minded if there were a bit more romance or another main female lead in the story, but the show's still fine as it is.


Overall: 9/10

A great show. If you mainly watch harems, shounens and action-SOL like, me this will be a great refreshment and change from all those. You will get unique comedy and very loveable characters packed into an interesting story. What do we want more?


I recommend watching the miniseries before every episodes, its really funny!


*As always, thanks for reading! If you have any ideas on how I can improve my reviews, feel free to tell me! I'd love to hear some feedback.

Seishū Handa is a twenty three year old male who is a pro calligrapher. After reacting badly to criticism of his work he retreats to Gotō Island on his father’s demands in order to help himself grow as a calligrapher and as a person. Along the way he interacts with various people allowing him discover his true self and look at life in a more calming manor.
Its funny when you look at anichart's line up and see that show that you know will be great. When I first came across Barakamon I automatically knew that I would love this show and I wasn’t disappointed.



Barakamon is an anime released in the summer of 2014. The anime was directed by Masaki Tachibana who did work on two shows that I’ve yet to watch ‘Ghost in the shell’ and ‘Noir’ and the show was written by Pierre Sugiura who is pretty much unknown. Both of who had the task or creating this show which may have made the job easier by using source material from the manga. 


Story:

The story is about building Seishū’s character and making him see life in a more relaxed manor. There is no overlaying story as it’s more focussed on character development and the relationships between main and side characters. The majority of the time it feels like a vacation and soon it feels like home. Seishū’s relationship with Naru is the main point of the series as Naru brings out the fun and maternal instincts in him which would have been hard to believe from episode one. To sum up the story is simply a sweet tale about development as an individual and becoming better then Seishū thought he could ever be. 


Characters: 

Seishu is our main protagonist and pro calligrapher. He is a very uptight man who can’t except criticism of his work and is very childish when it comes to loosing in calligraphy contests. From the get go he appeared to be a very boring individual. After he moves to Gotō Island he realizes how poor the living conditions are in comparison to technologically advanced Tokyo. He finds it hard to adjust at first and being persistently bothered by our secondary main six year old Naru doesn’t help. By the end of episode one he eventually understands the criticism given to him of his work and that’s when he begins to develop himself as a calligraphist and as an adult. The time he spends on the island helps him to realize that there is more to life than just his work and although he values calligraphy dearly he learns that time away from work and time with people who make you happy can have a positive impact on his life. 


Naru is our second main character. She is a bubbly an energetic six year-old that enjoys spending time with others and loves doing strange activities like catching bugs. Naru brings out the maternal side in Seishu which is very sweet. The two had a rocky relationship at first but they eventually developed a strong friendship. Naru is also more intelligent and more grown up than she appears at times but still retains her childish attributes. As for the rest of the cast they are very strong and each gets a relative amount of screen time. 



Art:

The artwork is very good the characters have there own individual designs. (Though Naru does have the big Moe eyes) The animation is very solid done by studio Kinema Citrus who are relatively unknown and haven’t done much. Black bullet is one other of there works that I’ve watched. The scenery in the anime is beautiful, such as the sunsets that Seishu gazes at. 		


Sound: 

The music score was done by Kenji Kawai who is notable for his work in Death note, Ghost in the shell and Higurashi. It has a very soothing and childish sound which matches the tone of the series. The opening SUPER BEAVER performed by Rashisa was excellent and the ending theme Innocence by Noisycell was spectacular and was the song of the summer for me and may be song of the year potentially.


Negatives: 

There’s few and far between problems with this show. I think the only problem this show is that despite its nice and calming nature, not many people will get into this series. This could mainly because most of the people I hang around who like anime want action, demons and or harems and would not take interest in beautiful shows like Barakamon. Shows like Usagi drop are a good example of nice and calming shows that won’t be as popular as others mainly because it doesn’t have any hard hitting action or storyline and this saddens me. Other than that the comedy can be hit or miss but it doesn’t take away from the overall score of the show. 


Final verdict:

Barakamon is a very sweet and beautifully done anime that I definitely hold dear in my heart. It may not be an astounding anime but its well worth the watch. Anyone expecting action packed demon/harems should stay clear and those looking for more beautiful and peaceful things to watch then give this a try. Overall 7.8 out of 10 


Similar anime to watch are the aforementioned Usagi drop. 


Thanks for reading guys, Have a nice day!

Barakamon was considered one of the best animes of 2014. Well i really can´t tell you much about cause i just watched some animes back from 2014 but at least for me, i think it deserves that title. 
I did not find bad points here, but that doesn´t mean it is perfect. I would consider this anime good but nothing more than that. Why do i say such thing? Well i will explain it on each topic. 
Story: (6/10).  The story is not bad. But it is not original nor creative. In fact, this story is something that probably you already saw in movies,tv shows or even in other animes. On my case, i'm tired of it. The city guy who is angry with life so he goes living in some rural city and learns the value of friendship and all that kind of stuff .. meh over explored. 


Although we do have some nice moral lessons that's why i gave it 6/10. For a slice life it's a good show and tell us important things. 



When i started watching this show, i expected something completely new. I was expecting some nice deep relation between Kanda and Naru(our main characters). While Handa is a 23 years old calligrapher who was mad with his own life after getting a bad grade from the director of an exposition, Naru is a 6 years old girl who just stared her life and is still innocent to all kind of dificulties that life can bring. 


But ... meh they blowed it up. I think they had something great there, they could had gone much more deep into Handa feelings and making them contrast with Naru's feelings but.. as i said they just did the usual. We see him adapting to the town and nothing else besides that. This does not mean that they failed, it just could be better. 


Art: (9/10): The landscape, the sunshine, the calligraphy that Handa does.. everything looks excepcional. The characters also look great, and the design fits perfectly with their personality. Especially Naru, it just looks so nice. 


Sound: (7/10): The soundtrack looks nice, but it isn´t nothing that we will remember in a near future. The opening is cool but the rest is just normal. 


Character: (7/10): Well they are nice, they look nice, BUT THEY ARE NOT ORIGINAL. We don´t have anything new ! And we just see development in Handa .. the rest has a really weak development. Well for 12 episodes long we couldn´t expect more .. but still i can´t give it a good rate because of it. All the characters were copied from other films or whatever .. Nothing new at all. I was having a deja'vu while i was watching this. Again, this doesn´t mean that they are bad, but they aren´t good either to deserve a better rate. 


Enjoyment: (9/10). Well Well finally we got here. I think even though not being excepcional, this anime excels pretty well in terms of entertainment. The comedy is good, the enviroment is awesome(I actually felt or at least imagined how it would be like if i was in the same position as Handa.) We can feel the peace of the town and all the good feelings that we can take out of there. Plus having in each episode, important lessons that can help us in our daily lives is actually pretty interesting.  


Overall, this anime is good but we can´t deny that it has nothing new to show. Although i advise you all to watch it because it is a nice show and really can entertains us well. But don´t expect something deep out of here. In fact this anime does not have any deep moment, it didn´t reached my heart in anyway, i mean there is just comedy and slice life. No drama, no romance, nothing related to it exists here. So if you are looking for something like that, don´t try this one.

Japanese calligraphy is occupied by several young geniuses, masters and newcomers. Among them all, seishu Handa, a rising star of this closed world. He collects excellent prices and recognitions. So he has all, he is young, beautiful and talented. His problem? His arrogance and confidence. One day, when a gallery director criticize his work, Handa get excited and hit him violently in the face. The young man is forced to go into exile on a small island at the bottom of the deep Japanese countryside. This penance would have been for him a sort of spiritual retreat in order to give new artistic momentum. Whileit is a regular in the town and cities, he landed in a place more quiet, deserted. It will be invaded by kids, and therefore will not even work quietly, relax a while. The neighbors arrive unexpectedly, his house is considered as a playground ... Impossible to work.

In super rhythmic episodes we will discover new characters and what Seishu Handa will do to accomplish his aims and create his identity in calligraphy.


My thoughts:


The bet is successful here, especially the design: the characters are beautiful and the scenery too, everything is colourful and gives an atmosphere of constant good humour.


on the other hand, the atmosphere can also have very dark moments during the sensei depressions. The dynamism of the anime is a strong point and the funny parts too. Naru has a very important role in the comedy of this anime because it is the driving force, almost the main character. Naru is a little girl of 7 years, it is still in the paws of the sensei with his friends in the area. It is early, eager to see them leave, then befriends with them and discovers the joys of country life. He, who has lived for calligraphy, discovers the outside world and relationships with people. He becomes indebted to the generosity of people and gladly accepts to render services to the people always with a touch of humour because the situations and Handa’s reactions are often inappropriate. So we have here a very valuable life lesson without being judgmental. The serious side is also well highlighted, including Sensei’s introspection about his behaviour, his life and his artistic future. The range of character is important and each person is someone who really gives a unique charm to this story.


Finally, the ancestral art which is calligraphy is brought here from very light manner but we understand that practitioners have a real philosophy of life. Through anime/manga, it always manages to discover something from Japanese folklore, here is calligraphy but this very original way of presenting things is exceptional and barakamon is a crush for me!

"It's best when there's nothing special."
That one line perfectly describes the entire series. Even if this show were just the first episode as an OVA, I wouldn't have hesitated to give it a 10. In fact, I added Barakamon to my all-time favorite anime list after the second episode. Somehow my gut was telling me that I would not be disappointed until the end. Unless you count the show ending as a disappointment in itself.
As in: "There are no more episodes ;_;", NOT "Wow, the ending sucked."
Story: 10;
The next sentence will sound very cheesy, so maybe grab some nachos. There is no story to speakof, because the story is life itself. The story can be summed up as "the struggle is real, but worth it in the end." From the synopsis, you wouldn't think you could relate to a "young, handsome, talented, narcissistic young man." Especially something as out-of-the-ordinary to a Westerner as a calligrapher of all things. I was half expecting Sei to be fairly unlikable and unrelatable as a character.


But really, you could be ANYONE and still find ways to relate to Sei's struggle as he finds his muse. This isn't just about an artist heading away from the loud city to find his inspiration in the countryside. It's about maturing as a person and learning to look around once in a while - you might find friends from all walks of life.


Art: 9;

The art wasn't anything outstanding, but everything was exactly as it should be. Character reactions were always funny when they were supposed to, and conveyed the proper melancholy all the same. What I really loved was the representation of rural Japan, especially in a few "inspiring" scenes.


Sound: 10;

The OP is catchy and the lyrics describe the show very well; didn't care much for the ED.


However, listening to the soundtrack while doing *anything* will give you the impression of flying in a hot-air balloon while wearing a particularly colorful party hat. And there is a parade of small forest animals all wearing very small party hats beneath you as you fly over them. (See "Kodomo no Kanchigai" and "Kodomo to no Kouryuu" from the OST to understand what I'm talking about.)


But then... the wind blows your party hat away and you feel strangely melancholic, and then nostalgic for a place you have never visited but is somehow present inside your soul.


The voice acting was spot-on for all of the characters (especially the main duo played by Daisuke Ono and Suzuko Hara). Finally, a child character played by an actual (talented) child instead of a grown woman with an annoying and squeaky voice!


Character: 9;

I'll be honest, aside from three or four characters, not all of them were memorable or anything. It was a shame, but some felt very underused. In fact, I even hated one of them. Even though I understand his role in the story was to give the main character some self-reflection material. He was plain annoying, and I can't stand his voice actor in anything but one role. Funnily enough, he tends to shut up in that role most of the time :^)


In any case, they shouldn't all be memorable. That's how life is. Think back to the most memorable days in your life, in any setting (not necessarily happy). Do you remember everyone in the room, outside, or wherever it was? Or even half of them? Unless those days were spent with just one or two people at all times, that's unlikely.


People are somehow just there at the right time to create the scene, and years after they fade away from memory.


ᴬˡˢᵒ ᴱᵐᶦ ᵇᵉˢᵗ ᵐᵒᵐ


Enjoyment: 10;

There would be moments where I couldn't get through 10 seconds of the episode without pausing to catch my breath. Some episodes would have me laughing my ass off in the first 20 seconds. Still, comedy is not the only thing Barakamon is good at.


I laughed, I cried, I laughed while crying, I cried while laughing. There was one scene towards the end where my mind was so conflicted about whether to do one or the other, I ended up doing neither. It was like seeing an old  friend across the street, trying to yell their name, but as you open your mouth you hilariously choke on your words like in a slapstick comedy.


To me, making me go through such a range of emotions in quickfire succession is the mark of a good show. 


Overall: 10;

If you haven't guessed already, I really liked the show. So much so that this will probably be my first and only review on this website. Don't get me wrong, I've had shows I loved just as much, if not more than Barakamon. I've had moments where I'd thought about reviewing Berserk 1997 (since I watched it 2 times in a row in the span of a week), or Welcome to the NHK. But even then I couldn't find enough words (or care enough) to properly convey my feelings towards them.


This show made me giggle like a little kid again. It made me wonder why I hadn't done so in a while too. After episode 11, I almost didn't want to watch the finale.


Then the show would never end.

Barakamon was a great relaxing show and one of the most funniest and playful anime I’ve ever watched. It had a very simple plot line, great characters, and events that made you laugh your head off throughout.
Though not much is going on, something is always going on and episodes 1-12 never let you get bored. With the most overdramatic characters and moments, it is a great show to watch for all ages.
Not to mention, my favourite character Naru is just the cutest person ever.
Plot 10/10 – As said before, it is a very simple plot line. The main character is banished to a remote islandto find inspiration on how to be a better calligraphy artist after he disrespected his boss. This  does centre around calligraphy, but doesn’t focus the entire show on that one thing; instead, it focuses on the main’s characters development and the people on the island itself.


Art 10/10 – The art was very pleasing to look at, but wasn’t too overwhelming. It had great lighting and colours that mixed well together, and I overall enjoyed it.


Characters 10/10 – The characters were very simple, but we got to know a majority of them over the course of the 12 episodes. The main character and one of the side characters were specifically focused on, and we were able to see how they each transformed into different, yet better people and how their relationship got closer.


Overall 10/10 – This was a really fun anime to watch that didn’t have any complexity to it. The characters were fun to watch and even though not many events happened, it was entertaining. I’d recommend this anime to people of all ages and to anyone who just wants a relaxing, fun anime to watch.

Barakamon is really for the slice-of-lifers like me. I bet going to an island as beautiful as the one in Barakamon's is part of a slice-of-lifer's to-do list. Anyhow, I loved the simplicity of it all. The anime was so natural; far from cliché. Very realistic - it was like animating someone's life. And the moments - the moments were so perfectly placed. 
Imagine this: you, on your early-twenties, surrounded by the beauty of nature; in an island with kids, not in your range of age, doing simple "islander" activities like fishing, swimming in the beach one hot afternoon, enjoying a festival, etc. If youliked the thought of these, I would recommend you to watch this anime.

Is this anime worth watching?  YES!  Why?  Hmmm... well if I had to compare this anime to something, I would say it feels like eating a really nice meal with your close friends and family.  After you eat the meal, everyone is satisfied and the next day you wish you could repeat the experience all over again.    
Characters: 10 / 10 - The shows greatest strength!!!
The main character, Seishu Handa, is a quirky adult in search of his "own" style of calligraphy.  His absolute focus on calligraphy and how it shapes his decisions and interactions with thepeople around him creates a very entertaining and fun story.  I love that he isn't some cliche highschooler who makes cringy and idiotic life choices.  In short, he is awesome!    


As fun of a character as Seishu is, Naru really completes the dynamic of the show.  Her innocent, adventure, fun-loving personality is really fun to watch when she interacts with Seishu.  They are an absolute joy to watch.


There are also no annoying side characters!!! YES!!!  How often does that happen???


Music, artwork, plot: 7 / 10 


All done well and feel natural.  None of it really stands out, but for this show that's okay.   


Atmosphere: 10 / 10 - Second greatest strength!!!


My oh my!  This show delivers every episode on a satisfying, comfy experience.  It is an extremely wholesome anime that just gives you that sigh of contentment.  The interaction between Seishu, Naru, and the villagers is executed perfectly.  


Recommendation:  WATCH!!!!!!!!!!!


It's not that this anime does something that you haven't already seen before, but that it does everything well.  If you want to watch something that will help you relax, have some laughs, and feel happy then this is the perfect anime for you.  This is definitely one of my favorites.

Sometimes you want to slow down from your shonen butt clenching, flahsback having, annoying voiced, thick action fun and have some feel good moments. At that i would have to say is the best phrase to sum up Barakamon.  Good feeling fun.
The intro alone let me know just how much i was going to enjoy nearly all of the characters and relationships. (namely the one between our protagonist Sei and Naru) Personally i have a warm place in my heart for shows that teach a little bit of how to find yourself with the help of people you wouldnt expect. If you dont carefor slice of life-ish shows you might want to avoid it i guess, but then again it does follow an actual story with emotional tension to it, so it bridges the gap a little bit. The only character i didnt really like was the newbe artist who is introduced halfway through the show. He is helpful for showing an immature view that our hero might have had when he was a younger and aspiring artist. Still he just came of as annoying and lousy to have around most of the time.


All be it a fantastic show you could argue that at points it can be slow or feel like not much is happening. Its not that i felt this to much but i can see where it might drag at a few points. I understand what Barakamon is about so i never had a pacing issue myself.


The dub was very enjoyable for those who prefer it that way. Robert McCollum, (the boi) who is probably most notable as Kougami from the Psycho-pass series, uses his smooth man voice to deliver a fantastic performance for our hero. Giving the lead a voice that commands a little respect made him a much more enjoyable character than if he had the voice of a typical light novel boy voice, and for the use of Robert McCollum i give the dubbing team a tip of the hat.


Naru may be one of the cutest characters in anime that I've ever come across, and in the best ways i find her to be a great representation of the child in not only Sei, but in whomever is watching the show as well. Naru was never used for anything thing other than feeling like a realistic 7 year old girl, and for that i am very grateful. It hurts my heart sometimes to see innocent characters used for some creeps fansevice shitfuck purposes. 


All in all i can't think of a bad time to be had watching this show. Even if its not your genre of choice you would still probably enjoy this. The art and characters are beautiful coupled with a nice story on learning to mature and grow as a person it will make you feel good all the way baby.


Final thoughts: I didn't mention the Calligraphy for some reason. It's like important but in the same respect it could be swapped out with a different passion and work just as well. Great fresh idea though, and that's the shit i like to see.

A big reason why I made this review is because I didn't quite understand why this anime was so highly rated, I didn't slog through this anime hating every minute of it but I didn't walk away feeling like this was 9 or 10 material. This is in the Slice-of-Life category and while yes this does have the atmosphere of a Slice-of-Life story I can't help but feel as if this anime is really overrated.
Story 6/10
I don't have that much to say over the story other than the way it wrapped up was absolutely fantastic, the last episode really hit me in the heart inthe best way possible. The acceptance and belief in the MC's choices made me very happy.


Art 9-10

The character designs and lineart was fantastic, I really loved the atmosphere and colors. If you're into eye-candy exclusively you're really gonna dig this anime a lot. 


Sound 6/10

It was what you should expect, I didn't really enjoy the opening song as much as I thought I would but it isn't like the OST of this anime is a bunch of "deets and doots" like Umaru.


Character 3/10

This is where this anime lost me, while Naru and the kid cast are really fun I can't help but feel like something was really missing. While Naru was the neighborhood scamp I never really got the feeling like she was a kid, I felt as if she was just a witty companion and they never go deep into her character.


Not to mention I didn't connect with any of the characters and feel any deep attachment. They were all very shallow and there wasn't a deep dive into any of the characters. Then again I understand that this show is 12 episodes long but apart from Naru and Hiroshi I felt like everyone else was just taking up screentime.


Although I won't be too harsh because this anime is all about making friends.


Enjoyment 6/10

I enjoyed the comedy in this show alot, and I didn't "slog" through this anime like I've done with other series that were highly rated yet very boring. 


Overall -- 6

If you want to bool out and slice of life this is definitely the show to do it with. 


(I rate like Fantano btw.)

It is rare indeed when I find a slice of life show I actually want to watch, let alone one that I consider one of my favorite shows. But Barakamon is different from many of those shows. Like many slice of life shows, it is character driven and focuses on everyday events instead of action and adventure. For the most part, I find these shows to be boring and unengaging, but Barakamon pulls you in through the top notch characters and underlying story. Truly a wonderful experience. 
The story is fairly simple, yet also very engaging. Handa-sensei exiles himself to an island after disgracing himselfat a calligraphy exhibition. His arrival to the island coincides with the start of summer and he finds himself constantly bothered by the neighbors children as he tries to reinvent his calligraphy style. Episode one covers his arrival to the island and his introduction to many of the nearby residents, including Naru. Many of the following episodes follow Handa's exploits on the island and many of his experiences start to shape his new calligraphy style. The audience is treated to a look into what country living is like in Japan, which is a nice reprieve from the constant Tokyo setting in many other anime. City boy Handa is often out of his element on the island and around his neighbors, but he ends up experiencing many things on the island that he didn't in Tokyo, including summer festivals, the ocean, and Bon festival. Through it all, Naru is a fixture is his life on the island and many of the other kids are impressed by the "Sensei" and follow him/force him to participate in their summer adventures.


The characters, however, are what make this anime amazing. Many of the supporting cast are hilarious and its fun to watch Handa try and navigate his way through their large personalities.  Most of them are largely defined by certain personality traits and none of them really change throughout the course of the story. And they shouldn't, because they are there to help Handa change, to help him see there is more to life than calligraphy or grand prizes. 


Handa and Naru's relationship is one of the centerpieces of this anime. Naru is interested in this new person and wants to play with him; Handa gets dragged along. At first, he is annoyed with her, he tells her to get out of his house, to stop bothering him. She is persistent, and she slowly worms her way in. She worries about him when he has to be hospitalized and he in turn worries about her at the beach. He wonders about her parents and what happened to them, on her birthday he's scared of disappointing her with a mediocre present. She becomes one of his best friends on the island, no matter how hard he tried at the beginning to make her go away. She helps him change as a person without realizing it, and she gives him inspiration in his calligraphy. In the end, even though he knows staying in Tokyo would be more practical, he chooses to go back to the island for Naru, and for everyone else. 


Handa's character change is also important. If he had stayed the same disgruntled, entitled city boy, this wouldn't have been an enjoyable anime. The contrast between his first drive to the village in episode one and his second drive in episode twelve comes to mind. In both, Naru's grandfather drives him from the airport to the village. In episode one, he is unimpressed by the view of the ocean. "It's just the ocean," he says. Whats so special about it. When confronted with the same view in the last episode he looks out and says, "It's gorgeous." Another example is his reaction to his results from the exhibitions he enters throughout the series. When he gets second place early on in the series, he is convinced that he is getting no where with his style. When he gets fifth place at the end of the series, he accepts it because he was proud of the work that he submitted. Seeing Handa struggle with reinventing himself throughout the series is an enjoyable watch, and it is through his friendship Naru and with everyone else that he is inspired to change and to grow and to write beautiful calligraphy. 


This is certainly the best slice of life anime I have ever seen. Most of the time I got lost in the episodes and when it was over i was honestly surprised it had been twenty minutes. The opening and ending are spectacular as well and the art is good, but I have seen better. All in all, this is a solid 10/10, I have no complaints. Truly perfect. 


(Scores: Story 10/10, Art 8/10, Sound 9/10, Character 10/10, Enjoyment 10/10)

Barakamon, that anime from 2014 that got largely ignored in favor of flashier, more popular series that aired the same year. However, Barakamon truly holds its own. Even though it isn't anything brilliant or truly thought provoking, it is a ray of joy that will always lift you up on your worst days.
Story 7
The story is simple and solid but is not the main focus of the anime. Essentially, a famous calligrapher has a melt down and decides to travel to a rural island to find inspiration for his work. Most of the series focuses on his interactions with people who live on this island.Overall very simple story, but it works.


Art: 7

Solid art. Nothing amazing but everything looks nice enough, especially on the island.


Sound: 8

Island sound is captured very well. Silence is used at just the right times. The opening and ending themes are both solid and capture the lighthearted and joyful nature of the anime


Character: 8

The main character is interesting enough, clearly struggling with social interactions and anxiety about his work. He develops quite nicely throughout the series. However, Naru, one of the little girls who lives on the island, completely steals the spotlight. Not only is she hilarious, but she also reminds us of the joyful and carefree nature of childhood that we so easily forget once we grow up. Truly an awesome character. Most of the side characters fall into a cliche but they are quirky and or funny enough to keep the viewer entertained.


Enjoyment: 9

I truly enjoyed the series. It would always light up my day and help me get through tough times. Just the right amount of cute, funny, and motivational to cheer up anyone!


Overall: 8

Yeah, with Barakamon, I don't think my heart has ever felt so full.
There's nothing that's ever worked better as a plot device than redemption and finding your roots again. With Barakamon we get just that. 
Handa's fall from grace was great to watch. It was a scenario many people of his age, myself included, can sympathize with. The idea that older people decide if we succeed or not and don't even understand is always frustrating, I know I got that struggle on a daily basis. 
As Handa tries to find his roots during his exile, the story of Barakamon truly comes to life. The ruralvillage is the perfect setting not only for him to perfect his craft but to humble himself and become someone worth cheering for. The major elements of the plot are quite predictable as a whole. The meddling kids who don't know how to stay away, Handa's growing love for the place that has seemed so annoying to him, his departure, his return, his rise after his fall from grace with his own identity in the calligraphy world intact, it isn't anything new, but it still works. The story still packs a punch and really hits you where it hurts. \n\n
The characters are likable and you come to love them as they become a huge part of Handa's growth. Naru Kotoishi has to be one of the cutest kids in anime to hold such a big art in it. I believe this dynamic is one that is almost foolproof and is growing in popularity. The big brother little sister dynamics works wonders. \n\n
The art is great all around. It's warm, bright, welcoming. It shed light on the world of calligraphy that I had no idea about and really add in highlighting some of the genius and madness that comes from the art form. \n\n
At just 12 episodes, the story comes and goes like the breeze and at the end you are left fulfilled and full of love and hope, if you're into that sort of thing. Barakamon is worth the watch, full of joy and happiness with hints of sadness, all of it in proper proportions. You won't regret watching this one.

Well, where shall I begin? There's nothing much for me to say actually. All I know is that this anime was very good and was worth watching. Thanks to the art and the story, this anime made me realize that anime isn't all about action, superpowers, horror and nudity. A good anime can also just be slice of life and comedy all together. The anime shows us the life of the villagers on a small island far from the big cities. After watching this, I really wanna travel to Japan and travel through the country side. I highly recommend this anime for those who lovescomedy and slice of life.

Disclaimer: This is my first review.
Barakamon is the first full blown slice of life I watched. (I had previously seen Devil is a Part-Timer, but because of its action I don't consider it fully slice of life.)
Story (7): The story was mostly episodic, with an interesting overarching storyline. I found all of the episodes to be interesting and the overarching plot engaging.
Art (8): The art was appealing and got the job done. It didn't need to do anything all that fancy, though I found the calligraphy in the show beautiful and looked forward to every piece that was created.
Sound (8): Nothing stood out in particular,though I found that the soundtrack fit perfectly with the show and its characters.\n\n
Character (9): This is where the show shines. I found all the characters interesting and unique. Naru, in particular, was very endearing and cute.\n\n
Enjoyment (8): I definitely enjoyed this anime. Though I was a bit hesitant at first, it quickly brought me in with its heartwarming story and interesting characters. I found myself eager to watch the next episode and finished the entire 12-episode show in two days. \n\n
Overall (8): Barakamon is a very good anime. Though I'm usually an action shonen junkie, Barakamon was a great change of pace, and has opened me up to an entirely unfamiliar but exciting world of slice of life. I highly recommend this anime to everyone, especially those looking for a jumping off point for slice of life. \n

I do not remember why I started watching this anime, but I have to say that I am happy that I was able to find this slice-of-life gem. 
To describe it with one word, Barakamon is sweet. Seishuu, the main character,  is completely out of his element on the island where he has moved, and his interaction with the people of the island as he clumsily and foolishly tries to adapt to their way of life is hilarious and innocent. 
Naru, the small girl who befriends Seishuu, is a character that you won't easily forget. She's tiny and adorable and her desire to alwaysplay and have fun awakens the child in every viewer. \n
I will admit this,   Barakamon seemed to go on for a long time, at least it did for me. It took me awhile to finish this anime. It can be a little slow and there were times that I forgot that there was an actual story. But when I finished Barakamon, I was satisfied.\n
I would recommend this anime to anyone who enjoys slice-of-life, comedy, or to someone looking for something sweet and cute.

Its seems in the last few years, slice of life anime has become very very popular. Look at the current titles getting rave reviews: Amaama to Inuzuma, Non-Non Biyori, and Udon no Kuni no Kiniro Kemari (Currently airing as of 10/2016).  This one is no different than those and I would argue better.
Sei Handa (the townsfolk call him "Sensei"), is a gifted calligrapher that seems to have lost his way mentally. He punches a renowned critic and is sent by his father to a remote island to "find himself". Over 12 episodes his adventures with the townspeople and his self-discovery lead him to becomea better person and finds that his real home is not in Tokyo but on the island.


Kotoishi Naru, the young girl our protagonist befriends has to be one of the cutest anime characters in recent memory even a bit mysterious as we find that she is being raised by her very busy grandfather so she ends up becoming the town "scamp", being raised by the village as a whole, she has taken a liking to Sei, and even misses him when he's gone. She is also filterless and with that helps Sei overcome some of his eccentricities. 


This anime is very light, very cute and very very enjoyable. A must watch for all lovers of the Slice of Life Genre... 12 Episodes you won't regret! 10/10

Recommended to watch if you: Want a show to relax to, with themes of nature, rural community (especially playing with kids) and rustic lifestyle. 
This show is in its essence a healing anime. It marks a retreat from overwork and stressful city life into the inspiring nature and rustic lifestyle of rural areas. 
And it does so exceedingly well. The show deals with themes of reclusion and stress juxtaposed with rural community and inspiration through nature. 
Following our somewhat burned out protagonist we as viewers experience the feeling of entering this new and very different environment alongside him. First the confusion and rejection, but thenalso opening up to it as time goes on, until you realize that you have already welcomed the quirky folk of the island into your heart. \n
If these may seem like very flowery expressions: This is the best way to describe your emotions watching this series as it intentionally creates moods and emotions rather than actual plots, just like other healing anime. \n\n
At some times the shenenigans of the kids in this show might be annoying to you and depending on your tolerance for hyperactive children this will affect you more or less strongly.

"Is this an Anime about a white guy that's living in a basement and draws some japanese characters on countless pieces of paper?"
"Yes"
But, before you click away because the story sounds hella boring (which to be fair, isn't wrong), give me a second and let my try to explain to you why this show is worth giving a shot. I'm not a "Slice of Life" fan. Not at all. And that's because slice of life often builds up to some kind of romance to keep the audience thrilled on to something. And jesus christ, japanese romance is the most cringeworthy shit on this planet. Barakamonis different. This Anime doesn't need romance to keep you watching. It delivers with wholesomeness. 


Seishuu Handa, the protagonist, flies to an island, meets friends and gets to know what living life really means. That's the whole story. No complications. No romance bullshit. But this Anime doesn't need a great story. It just needs simple joy with help of an 6 year old girl, that knows more about having fun then any other character. So if you're looking for something thrilling, something with excellent and thought out storytelling , go watch something different then this. But if you want to have an innocent show with great art [9] and characters [9], sit your ass down and watch Barakamon.

Barakamon, is really fun and easy going anime if you just want to relax, forget all about magic,fights and epic battles and join this funny bunch in their daily lives, actions, emotions, hardships and sillyness!
I know its quite short review but my advice is to watch it definitely or re-watch it even to remember the fun moments!
This anime is in my book just a relax kind of anime that puts a smile on your face similar to Acchi Kocchi,In Another World With My Smartphone and many others, BUT with a big touch of realism!!!

I know this anime came out quite a while ago and I've only watched it recently. However, I am too obsessed with this anime to not write a review. This being my first review, I wanted it to be about Barakamon. 
It is a 12 episode anime and about 20 minutes ish long. So it's not a long anime and doesn't have an amazing, action packed plot/story line. But I felt so connected to the characters and the relationship they develop over the 12 episodes. 
To be honest, at first, the story summary/synopsis was a bit meh. It seemed kind of boring and I wasvery hesitant to watch it and waste like a day. But with no other choice, and there was no other anime that really interested me. I took a deep breathe and jumped into the unknown. And boy was I glad. I went through this anime like popping chocolates while crying on Valentines day. 


I laughed, I cried and my heart felt all fuzzy. I have the lines all memorised and fall asleep listening to Ono Daisuke's voice (he voices Handa Seishuu). This is really a great anime and I regret not watching this earlier. 


This is such a heartwarming anime that could warm the coldest hearts. AND the opening and ending songs are ammmmazzing.

*might contain spoilers*
A child’s smile is brighter than any light in this world. Its warmth will leach into your heart and refuse to get out, glowing eternally in your soul. 
It will hold you tightly and never, ever, ever let go.
This is what I have learnt from the – totally being subjective – best slice-of-life anime series. 
“Barakamon” is a bittersweet (sweet with underlying tones of bitterness, I’d say in a dramatic manner) anime series surrounding Handa Seishuu, a young calligrapher, who ends up being exiled to an island for punching another famous calligrapher. 
Getting out of the city and into the rural area, anotherlife dawns on him as he learns to embrace the simplicity of life by meeting Naru, a tomboyish young girl who has a peculiar love for bugs, Hiroshi, whose parents who might have been founders of Handa Seishuu no Fanclub, and other people who contributed subtly to the person he slowly develops into.


[Characters: 10/10]


One word to describe the character development: brilliant. 


Since the first episode, we can clearly see that the creators of the series actually put effort into building multi-colored layers of personalities on the characters instead of just shoving them stereotypical -dere types. 


If Handa is a seemingly stoic person, Naru is a naturally cheerful girl with a radiant smile, or Tama, an I’m-totally-not-a-fujoshi fujoshi and her best friend, Miwa, a boyish and cool big sister… 


Furthermore, one thing that I particularly love about the anime series’ character development is that it allows us to slowly peel off the outward impression that the characters give to us and actually dig deeply into their genuine personalities – either Handa’s burning desire to find his identity, or Naru’s feelings of loneliness behind that smile… 


The creators have successfully hit our hearts in that way, asserting how we should never judge a person just by the things they try to display and their true nature lies in things they try to hide.


Just by seeing how much Handa has changed since coming onto the island, we can all put on a smile and book our ticket there. 


[Story: 9/10]


The story will make you literally fall off your chair because of too much laughter. Its jokes are relatable and hilarious – I bruised my forehead lots of times because of bashing my head against the desk from too much laughter, and so will you. 

These light-hearted jokes are, in fact, one of the reasons I consider this the best slice-of-life anime series ever. The other, of course, is how it makes you cry without you realizing it.


Instead of blatantly jerking tears from her eyes like some other slice-of-life anime series, “Barakamon” has these undertones of touching elements, waiting to be explored. One of the episodes especially gives us an insightful look behind Naru’s plastered innocent grin – that carefully enclosed loneliness that she tries to pen inside her heart and show to no one.


Another fact that made me tear up is that the person who realizes it is Handa.

Handa, Handa, Handa. Such a seemingly hot-headed, brash, stoic character… 


…and that moment when he mused “Maybe she is lonely after all”…


…I cried internally and stared speechlessly at the screen…


…just because of the sadness that sentence projected into my heart.


“Barakamon” is not a show purely for comedy. Sure, it has lots of it, but you can never disregard the depth of this series’ subtlety.


[Sound: 10/10]


The sound was, literally and figuratively, heaven to my ears.


The opening is light-hearted, just like Naru herself. Not only that, “Rashisa” by Super Beaver actually explores Handa’s character very skillfully as the song talks about being yourself – by far one of the wisest OP choices I have ever stumbled across.


The ending is a gentle song that elaborates the beautiful bond between Handa and Naru, and the appreciation he has towards her. “Innocence” by NoisyCell depicts just how tight she holds onto his hand, onto his mind, onto his heart and refuses to let go, determined to keep that mutual glow inside their hearts. A wondrous ED choice, I dare say.


Then, finally, something I am particularly pleased with is the OST of the anime series. “Toki no Nagare” by Kenji Kawai pulls heartstrings. Together with the context of the anime, it sends us across a passage of depths that the anime series subtly hints. 


The voice actors are amazing. Daisuke Ono, of course, pulls his role off flawlessly as always - his voice is simply perfection. The anime series seems to have hired child voice actors as well, which makes the roles even more real… and I mean, you should definitely check out the “Barakamon” seiyuu video. Naru’s seiyuu is the perfect symbol of adorableness. 


[Art: 9/10]


The art is painfully beautiful. Enough said.


[Enjoyment: 10/10]


Oh yes, I enjoyed it very, very, very much. This is one of the most memorable anime series that stayed in my mind for a long time since I finished watching it, and I will never forget the feelings it managed to make me display. Just… absolute masterpiece. Wow.


[Overall: 10/10]


This is the highest score I have ever given to an anime series. I love it and would recommend it to everyone around the world if I could. 


It is literally, and I mean it, 12 episodes of beauty.


“Once you carve your path, all that’s left is to walk it.” – Hiroshi Kido

The funny thing is i started off trying to watch this but i never came by to get it because i could not spell it or i just heard about it on a video here and there, but i am kinda happy i watched it. I was watch Handa-kun and after hearing about its predecessor i felt like i was missing something great. Handa-kun was okay in my opinion not horrid but this is on another level. 
Barakamon is one of the best slice of life animes i have ever seen and really has a captivating interesting story. The music is good for setting moodsand the art is way better than the newer show Handa-Kun. (not really spoiler because you will see in like beginning of first episode)The art really fits this slice of life and really brings out the love and happiness that the small village has and how close everyone is. The art is really easy on the eyes and makes you feel relaxed and happy. It is not off the charts but it is beautiful. 


 The characters are so unique and not only the main character ever single character is something else they are developed well and don't fail to support Handa all the way through. Handa made me cry a few times i wont lie he is such an amazing character and he would be an awesome person in real life. You feel very close to Handa and the emotions that character have for each other come out clearer than day. Even characters who are introduced for short while become quiet likeable and you can understand who they are and what they are to Handa and they are not forgotten easily.

A good example is the Handa's mom who is important to Handa and explains her position and how much she cares about him. She also is very understanding, yet  stubborn and unable to have her son change from just a loving kid. 


Besides that this show is just awesome it is not just an anime you watched because you have free time its an anime you want to give attention too and skip your summer homework and use your work time you planned for your self to stay up and do your homework but you spent it all watching Barakamon because you cant control yourself, because it makes  you fall in love with it once you start. 


Sorry for the personal bit but if wanna watch a good slice of life and want to lighten the mood watch this. Watch it good

What can I say, I love Barakamon.  I have watched it now over 5 times.  Whenever I'm feeling lonely, stuck in a rut or even when the weather is just a little depressing; Barakamon brings me back to a happy place.
I was never one for slice of life anime until Barakamon.  I was obsessed with Sailor Moon like story lines and even got into the gorey side of anime.  Then Natsu entered my life (the main child character) and I find myself still looking for the next Barakamon.  
Barakamon has the right amount of drama, comedy and "romance" a showneeds.  The characters are all intriguing and inspire you to just be yourself; love what you do and make no excuses.  The small town in Barakamon along with the animation made me reconsider "city living."  After each episode I longed for a simple village with a close knit community.  \n
If you're not into slice of life anime, this show will completely change you.  If you are looking for a slice of life show, none rival Barakamon.  Just watch it and you'll see why I can't stop watching it!

Okay I honestly did not know what to think about this anime from reading the synopsis. I am so glad that I ended up watching it though.  This anime was funny, cute, amazing, you name it.  The characters were really well thought out, each having their own unique personalities.  The story was okay, but I think that the characters were one of the best parts about this show.  My personal favorite was Naru, who was not only cute, but had the most fun personality (her facial expressions were honestly the best thing ever). My friend who almost never watches anime, watchedthis with me and could not stop laughing and wanting to watch more.  I think that in itself says a lot about this anime and how anyone can find enjoyment and laughter from it.  I highly recommend checking it out, you won't regret it!

This was a very cute anime to watch.  The story of the main character finding himself is lovable and the tidbits of humor thrown in makes this a wonderful anime.  I was left with little to no complaints at the end.  The artwork of the anime was one of my favorites in a long time.  I highly enjoyed the character design and scenery of each scene.  There was very little action throughout the story so if you're the one who is into heavy fight scenes, this anime is not that type.  However, I would highly recommend this anime ifyou're looking for the type of anime that simply brings you on a low action, peaceful story line full of well developed children.

Barakamon is a step back from all the crazy fantasy world anime's it has such an original plot and it ran with it.  Handa's back story is so unique and sets the anime up for great success. The bond between Handa and Naru is such a great bond they work together perfectly and with all of the supporting characters involved it has so many great aspects this anime is a must watch from its plot and it's character development you are sure to really enjoy every episode to it's core. Barakamon will not give you a huge climax but it sure does give youa warm feeling in your heart, the kindness of the villagers and the island itself is so heart warming and Handa's development from being so impulsive to being a very wise man. Meanwhile Naru is painted as a very goofy kid this may be true but once you dive deeper into her story your realize how important Handa is to Naru.

"Barakamon" is a sweet slice-of-life comedy about a young professional calligrapher who, upon retreating to a remote island to develop his style, meets the friendly neighborhood children. Although the characters are charming enough, I found the humor of the series to be weak. It was predictable and, at times, forced. Thus I would recommend watching its oft-compared work Usagi Drop instead. If you've seen that already, then give Barakamon a try!
Story [6/10]: As a rule of thumb, it's best not to expect too much plot from a slice-of-life anime, and Barakamon is no different in that regard. What it offers is completely expected, but sweetnonetheless. Unfortunately, the show uses much of the same imagery and tropes as most anime: beaches, fireworks, and festivals. Most of the plot devices are trivial occurrences.


Pacing [5/10]: Following a very rushed first episode, the anime slows down to a crawl and not much happens until near the end.


Art [7/10]: Aside from a few artistic risks, Barakamon does not really stray from the standard style. The animation is clean and crisp.


Sound [6/10]: The music was forgettable (so much that I remember none of it). The island dialect is pretty odd to listen to, but adds to the backwards charm of the show.


Character [6/10]: While the main character Handa initially comes off as the typical standoffish genius that indigenous to anime high schools, he quickly loses this composure. He displays a refreshing variety of traits, including klutziness and fervor for his art, which are sometimes inconsistent but mostly seem to work. Through the series, he loosens up and his relationships develop, but the other characters don't get such close treatment by a long shot. Even the little girl Naru barely receives any character development.


Enjoyment [6/10]: As a whole, I liked Barakamon well enough and would've enjoyed it much more if I'd found their comedy to be humorous. It does not rank as a must-see, but is a light and heartwarming time filler!


Overall: [6.5/10]

Slice of Life anime is a genre that recently I have been watching quite a bit of, and I have to say that Barakamon is probably the best series out in the genre. When I first saw this series, it was a few gifs or screenshots of the hilarious face Naru makes when she demonstrates her knowledge of kana and starts reading a milk carton. 
Short review: Other reviewers have talked plenty about the charm of the series, the humor, the plot, but I'd also like to note that I think this is one of the few anime that really captures the essence of childhood.I can imagine myself as a child behaving and saying many of the things Naru and the other children on the island say/do, including butt-poking, catching bugs and teasing adults about it, and thoughtlessly slapping handprints all over a new boat. What I think makes this series truly great is that it captures the humor and youth of children in a way that other anime series have not - and that is what makes it memorable and worth watching.
