No spoiler.
It felt like a Sunday afternoon if that makes any sense ;) Watch it, you’ll feel better afterwards.
It’s a heartwarming serie with nice humour. Nothing hilarious, still, it will probably put a smile on your face.
I really liked the simplicity of it all. The non-adventurous plot, animation, character design, everything is simple, which really enhances the plot: looking for inspiration as an artist.
I was happy that it didn’t get into any stupid over-the-top emotional drama, nor useless romance subplot. All episodes were nice to watch. It reminded me a bit of some Ghibli movies (Only yesterday, My neighbors the Yamadas).
I didn’t skip the openingand closing songs. Overall, it is a great anime.

So, you were on the internet and by accident you found an anime called Barakamon. What's that? Hmmm i don't know. Does it worth it? Well. Yes, if you want to laugh. The story follows Seishu Handa , a calligrapher who moves to the remote Gotō Islands off the western coast of Kyūshū, and his various interactions with the people of the island. IT'S A COMEDY.
So, what should i expect from a comedy?
Laughs, and a simple but consistent argument. 
Ok, so, tell Mr. Reviewer. What about the characters?
Well, there are no more than 5 or 6 recurrent characters, they're all funny in different ways aswe are used to (at least, if you use to watch comedy animes). I call it, "little town comedy". A "big city guy" moves to a small island. You can imagine. After watching one or two episodes, they start making the spectator feel part of the little island. Will Seishu Handa get use to live with these peculiar people? That's the funny part. The characters will definitely make you love the anime. 


So... the music? And the art?


The music complement decently the scenes. And the art is good enough. What we're gonna remember is the laughs, not the music or the art. But, yes, is good :) 


Despite that the characters are simply amazing, and considering it's a comedy that meets the expectations, i can say it's an 8/10. I have to be fair. I recommend this anime to all who wants to laugh and laugh :) 


I hope you find my review usefull.

**Some Spoilers in the review**
I very rarely write reviews. I was compelled to write after successfully finishing what probably is my first ever Slice of life anime. If there are any burdens, worries or concerns you are carrying in your life, probably from your work/ school/relationships and are looking for a feel good show that is guaranteed to give you temporary relief and probably reevaluate your life, this is the show for you.
            This anime is about a calligrapher who is a sensitive individual and has finished 2nd and is ina state of depression, self hate and shame. He is sent off to an island by his family and business associate to recover and take some time off. The episodes are all pretty much about the protagonists' experience with the people and the beauty of that island, how it helps him in rejuvenating his mood. It all sounds like a simple narrative, but it was masterfully executed with loads of lighthearted comedy and precious moments of transcendence. 


           What I loved the most about this anime was how relatable the protagonist was to me and any grown up in general and how we can learn some things from this anime. We have a lot of  things we worry about in life and if we think hard about it, most of these concerns (aside health of our loved ones) are materialistic. Goddamn, our priorities are often so backward. This anime has a subtle message to the viewers that life and world are too beautiful to be moping around or worried. 


The protagonist by the end does not achieve the professional success he hopes to achieve at the beginning of the series. But he transforms into a person that is complacent with that result and is more about doing work he personally can appreciate. I am sorry if you weren't wanting to read this part. But watch the anime, his profession is only an accessory to the plot. The story is more about his experiences and maturing into a complacent individual with better priorities. 


Two of the best anime I have ever seen are Space Brothers and Barakamon. I wish they made more anime like these where adults and youngsters have some life lessons in there. If you know some more of that sort, please recommend.


P.S.: I don't really grade art, sound and what ever other elements are usually listed out and graded separately by pros. This is 2014 ffs, almost every anime has watchable art compared to 20 years back.

Barakamon tells the story of a calligrapher in stagnation. After an... uneventful encounter with an art appraiser, he leaves Tokyo and goes to a small village in a remote island. There, he makes friendships and finds inspiration for his art.
The anime is cheerful and light. It is what you are looking for if you want quality non-violent, non-complicated, non-dramatic entertainment. Which is getting rarer to find nowadays, so it is a breath of fresh air. While the anime did achieve its goals very well, the genre makes it difficult for it to become THE legendary anime everyone is hyped about and will remember after watching.
Story(this section might contain spoilers):

The initial premise of the anime is solid. I would say the anime kept with it well. Of course, there isn't much happening story wise. We get to follow the day to day little things that make the calligrapher evolve and mature as a person and artist. Not having much to tell in a story is ok as long as it allows for the anime to flow, which happens with Barakamon. However, it can not be considered something out of this world. In the end, it is a simple story, a good one, but still.

7/10


Art:

The art is spot on. It is the best I could hope for an anime of this kind. The style fits the story and characters well, making a great ambience overall. However, I can't give it a 10 because anime is first and foremost, animation. Other animes display a higher level of animation with intricate battles and special effects, which Barakamon can not display. Which is ok, it just means it is not the best animation if the anime industry.

8/10


Sound:

I liked both the opening and ending. The sound worked well with the art and achieved the chill and light ambience for the anime. However, it is nothing earth shattering either.

8/10


Characters:

Character development was the main focus of this anime.  And overall, it did a good job. The evolution of the main character is well presented and credible. As such, the main goal of the anime is achieved. However, some secondary characters seemed pretty basic and unpolished to me, even after being there pretty much the whole time. But that's ok, after all, they are secondary characters. No characters seemed particularly charismatic/memorable to me.

7/10


Enjoyment:

Barakamon is one of these animes that make you wish you could just drop everything and enjoy life with energetic children around dragging you here and there. And because it made me wish so, I would say the anime was successful and made me enjoy the show. I liked it. But again, it is not something exceptional. 

7/10


Overall:

Barakamon started with a good premise, and stayed loyal to it to the end. It has a very simplistic nature achieved with good art and music. Because of said simplicity, some characters remained perhaps unexplored. But perhaps this is one of the reasons why the anime has a  simple, light feel to it.

Overall, Barakamon achieves its goal. That is, to be a happy and cheerful experience, but not something particularly memorable. It is a good anime.

7/10

2014 has given me so much awesomeness.
This is one of them.
An impulsive calligraphy prodigy whose exiled to small island in Japan called Gotou, Handa Seishuu. Handa, just like me, have no expectations of how his live in the village will be. Moreover, the first day of his moving on to the village, he encountered crazy peoples. But the most notable is an hyper little girl named Kotoishi Naru. And just like me, Handa doesn't expect what magic does Naru have in her pocket.
And then the opening starts. Epic, fucking catchy, unskippable performance by Super Beaver. The opening video supports it in every way possible.
The journeybegins.

I'm a big fan of Comedy, but Slice of Life tag? Not really. So i don't expect so much from the series.


How does it feel to get your expectations exceeded, again?


Barakamon is way too funny.

City boy in 'alien' place with all his awkwardness of situations, unexpected experience of a strict-raised, not to mention his Narcissism and immaturity. Along with ecstatic 7yo girl  with her squad that's not losing in terms of annoying. Plus village teens and their youth spirit combined with crazy personalities. In addition, the rest of villagers is just as lunatic.

The character department never lacks. The main character's development is depicted so well. And Naru, well, you'll know why i love this cute trouble machine so fucking much. The other characters is also very much entertaining.

Slice of Life anime needs to emphasize the character. And Barakamon do just that.


The story revolves in slow pace, but nevermind boring. You won't. Unexpected situations, awkwardness in the midst of beautiful nature scenery, surprising words coming from children's mouth, amazing etc.

And the feels amount this anime gives is bountiful. So you can laugh your ass off while feeling little memory pain in heart. "Ahh, so this is what it feels like to be kids again". You can't help but falling in love with this.


The art is of 2014. Pretty works. And the scenery feels like painting. Stunning. Not the strongest subject, but still worthy to be amazed.


The VA is not an all-star parade. You can feel Daisuke Ono award's aura here. But the totality of the cast is something different. And they use ACTUAL KIDS to voice over the kids. I can't really imagine the situations in the studio, haha. The voice of Naru,Suzuko Hara, is so cute. Did i tell you the ending song is just as awesome? 10/10


This anime is a very definiton of Expect the 'what you don't expect from a series' Unexpected and a powerful blockbuster.


Cracking, full of feels, refreshing, exquisite, pure work of Maestro. Barakamon is worth every minute spent. One of the best work in anime of 2014.


TL;DR Naru is Love, Naru is Life.

Any show that starts of with a guy punching an old man is gold in my book. It’s got humor, a somewhat unique take on the city boy in the country idea, and some really feel-good moments. Let’s get started!
Story:
So the story starts off with Seishuu Handa, who after having his calligraphy insulted by that old man you saw earlier, he punches him. To avoid the public after such a scandal, his father suggests that he go on a leave of absence to the country and work on his calligraphy from there. Here he meets tons of people, who welcome him with open arms andwho he gradually becomes close friends with. Something to be noted is that the show doesn’t ignore his punching the Director, and it brings it back up in actually a pretty series and realistically handled light.


I think what I love most about this show is the sense of community. Every character feels very real and necessary, and you really get a true sense of friendship and kinship of these people. For instance, in the first episode Seishuu needs to unpack his things, but he has a lot of stuff. Without even being asked, the entire neighborhood shows up to help, and to them it’s completely normal. In these few stills that come after that, I get more a sense of friendship than most shows can give you in a whole season, and this show is packed with moments like that.


As far as the story itself goes, it’s pretty basic. A city boy going to the country to find himself is by far no new concept, and it’s been done to death in films in particular, one thing I liked about this show was the use of Calligraphy. You rarely see it mentioned, at least in North America, and it really showed me a whole world of art. The animation and art of the calligraphy itself looks legitimately beautiful, which is great because it wouldn’t be any good if the calligraphy that’s supposed to be done by a master looks ‘average’. Another note is not something the show exactly did, but what it didn’t do. They left out all of the “oh I’m a city boy in the country everything’s confusing” for the most part. While it’s still present, it certainly isn’t a main factor in the plot, and Seishuu does a fair job of adjusting to the country life pretty quickly.


Still, my main complaint I’d say is that while it succeeds in using this plot to be pleasant, it’s not nearly as ambitious as it could’ve been, and seems content with being just ‘great’, rather than being ‘amazing’. There are a fair amount of times that the comedy just completely flops, and you’re left wondering what exactly was supposed to be funny. The humor itself is pretty standard, and usually doesn’t try to do anything unique from a comedic standpoint, which resulted in some episodes I found to be a little boring, especially when you can tell it’s trying really hard to make you laugh. But when it relaxes and just let’s the humor play second fiddle, it can actually be pretty funny. In this case I’ll compare it to my favorite Slice of Life, Usagi Drop. Usagi Drop often does not try to be funny, and even the humor that is there usually isn’t laugh out loud but still feels natural, pleasant, and fitting. This show has times when it feels like some of the humor is there because “it had to be”, rather than feeling natural like it should. Most of this out of place humor usually is present during the first 5 to 10 minutes of the episode, and then fades out and is replaced by more natural humor and a lot more of the feel good, touching moments that this show is loaded with. If you’re not smiling by the end of an episode, there must be something wrong with you. From start to finish very enjoyable, and an extremely satisfying ending to boot.


Characters:


I find Characters generally to be the sole most important factor in a show. Characters can hold up poor animation, even a shoddy plot, but with bad characters, you’re not going to want to watch the show, even if the plot is good. Like I mentioned earlier, these characters are amazingly good. Every one, even the side characters, feels unique, necessary, and great. From the wise yet amusing elders, to the bursting-with-energy little kids, they’re all very love-able.


I really liked Seishuu’s progression over the series. He starts off as a impulsive pessimistic workaholic, but after becoming a part of this community he begins to see how much more there is to life, and from this he gains inspiration for his work. He has a really nice dynamic with the people around him, and you can’t not love his interactions with the kids.


I found Naru and Hina and all the children to be delightful characters in their own light as well. Properly done kids is such a hard thing to find, with the last one I saw being Usagi Drop. But when child characters are done right, it really works. There’s so much you can appreciate about a child-like view of things, how everything is so simple and obvious, and the world is so full of wonder and mystery. Naru really is the perfect compliment to Handa’s character. Hina at first I thought would be one of the really weak characters. It starts of with her seeming to be a gimmick-based character, with the gimmick being that she’s shy and quick to tears, but the show quickly developed her out of this, and while she doesn’t do a whole lot throughout the run, Hina was just a very cute and fun little girl throughout.


I also liked seeing these characters that look up to Handa, Hiroshi, who is inspired to work harder after seeing Seishuu’s hard work, and Kousuke, who idolized him and is a up-and-coming calligrapher as well. Both were interesting in their own way, and I particularly liked how through their interactions with Handa, both discovered something about themselves and Handa as well. We get the idea that Kousuke is a lot like Handa was before coming to the island, and this provides a nice contrast between how Handa has developed and grown as a character.


That said, there are some weaker characters, Tamako and Miwa in particular. These characters came off as a little annoying, almost mean-spirited at times, and often-times their disrespect towards Seishuu could get pretty tiresome. With the kids it’s not so bad, they’re kids, they’ll do these things, and at least they’re cute while they do it, but these are middle school students, they really don’t have a good excuse to be acting the way they do. For instance, in one scene it’s shown that Miwa has made copies of Seishuu’s house key and has given them to everyone, and in another scene they try to peek on him when he’s in the bath, and turn the heat up on it to scalding hot. I don’t find that funny, it’s just mean and being a jerk. Along with this there was the second dynamic of Tamako being obsessed with manga, and the whole lame misunderstanding that comes from when she sees Seishuu and Hiroshi ‘hugging’. It didn’t stay funny for very long, and her character had about as much depth as a kiddie pool.


Animation:


The animation is good. I can’t really go into much more depth than that. It’s not exactly exceptional, being neither incredibly smooth, or breathtakingly beautiful, but it’s not bad either. It has a pleasant look to it, with some wonderfully painted backgrounds bringing life to the country. However, you can clearly see the animation is not super smooth, and there is a fair amount of still shots without any animation at all. That said, I do have to give credit to the actual calligraphy as I said before, because the animation and design of it looks really good. The character designs as well are nice, though I did at first look think Naru was a boy, but I don’t think that was entirely unintended.


Sound:


This show sounds nice. Both the Opening and Ending songs are really good and very pleasantly fit the mood of the show, and generally the OST was fine, though it didn’t really stand out to me. Occasionally the background music can stand out a little too much and be kind of unfitting. Though it wasn’t super preventable and generally wasn’t to this extent, a good example would be one scene in episode 11 that really failed. The music starts off with a somewhat dramatic tone, but the song doesn’t end. It just keeps going. They have a few jokes, but the humor bombs due to the unfitting music. When it finally changes, it changes to an overly sappy song that was only a minor improvement and still unfitting. After this the episode was fine, but it was still a strange issue.


Final Thoughts:


Overall this was a really satisfying and pleasant show. While it suffered from some issues with humor, it succeeded in having a great sense of community which a lot of shows lack, and it never failed to leave me without a smile on my face. It’s an incredibly satisfying and enjoyable show, and I definitely think it’s worth checking out.


(Originally Written October 9th, 2014)


https://writtenandwriting.wordpress.com/

Simple.
If there is a word that neatly sums up this series, "simple" it is. The idea of simplicity is present in every facet of the show, all the characters lead very simple countryside lives, have simple motivations and a simple attitude towards other people, which boils down to "be friendly to others and they will be friendly back." All events that take place in the island are quite unremarkable and mundane (one of the symptoms of being a slice of life comedy). All about this anime is quite basic, except for Handa, the protagonist. A frustrated calligrapher struggling to find an identity for his work,sometimes a petty rich boy, sometimes a daring artist. His learning from the new home and embracing of a more carefree life describe his character arc, and make him a symbol for those who desire to lead tranquil lives.


"Stressed young man moves to rural town to find new meaning in life and improve his art". When I first read this premise I looked down on it. My preconception was that the series would be some mumbo jumbo about how miserable modern civilization makes us and how we need to reconnect to nature. Luckily, that was not the anime's intention, its focus is actually on human interactions.


And how great those interactions are! The pair that steals the spotlight is Handa and Naru, the latter being one of the best little kids in all of anime. They have the funniest and sweetest conversations in the entire series, it is not overselling to say that you watch the show for these two. The rest of the cast is solid as well, although nowhere near as charismatic as the duo, they all have funny moments and do not come off as tropes. The other character besides Handa with a clear development throughout the series is Hiroshi, even if his arc is a bit rushed and could have been more fleshed out.


One of Barakamon's more remarkable accomplishments is how it demonstrates the characters' lifestyle, a very important task considering it is the basis for the main concept of the show. Even if you watched the anime soundless and unsubbed, you would still understand the villagers through their character design (generally short hair, plain clothes such as t-shirts, shorts, sandals, hardly ever wearing school uniforms) and mannerisms. This serves to contrast with Handa, who is always fidgety, paranoid and wore traditional kimonos before changing to casual clothes once he got integrated to the community. The exception to the rule is Hiroshi, who does not sport the carefree visage, reflecting his adolescent wish to move away to achieve greater goals, but still unable to leave his hometown.


The portrayal of simplicity is not perfect, however. Even the loveable characters can not make up for some of the uninventive storylines. Summer festival and beach episodes are the most infamous among 'fillers', and even if in Barakamon these episodes are not complete garbage, they feel lazy and take the viewer away from the experience of the otherwise good series.


Barakamon is sweet and heartwarming. It does not have the most complex themes or characters, but achieves everything that sets out to do competently, even if it could have expanded in several directions and chose not to in favor of consistency. Nevertheless, it is a good anime series. For all these reasons, and having possibly the best depiction of real children in anime, I suggest you watch it, especially if you are going through a particularly chaotic period of your life.

This anime is an absolute joy to watch. It's about a calligrapher who goes to an Island and get befriended by the locals. That's basically it. It's got very little story. You watch the character live in life on the Island and have fun with the locals. It's benevolent, it's funny, the animation style adds to the humor, it's real with character's having understandable flaws which if anything makes them more likable, the translation is great with local islanders having dialogue as if they were from the rural part of the United States, the relationships the main calligrapher develops with the kids on the Islandare extremely touching without being sad, and the music is excellent. Not just the opening theme, but the ending theme is incredible as is the music that plays during the anime. The only two things that come to mind that may be an issue are the mother is a little to physical in her interactions with the characters (at one point she is literally punching another character in the face because of something he said) and given the very loose story and lack of drive from episode to episode it may not be as good if binged watched. These are very small complaints. This is my favorite anime since Tokyo Ghoul. It absolutely wonderful and definitely worth watching. 10/10.

There isn't really an antagonist, just struggles for the protagonist in which the children help him see how to overcome the problems he faces. I highly recommend this Anime ifyou enjoy COMEDY.\n

This anime caught my attention as soon as I watched the first episode. I watched it all the way through in less than a day. Finding myself disappointed when there was no button to go to the next episode because it's just so great to watch, all of the feelings are there. Ah I can't really think about how to review this anime because I just can't stop thinking what if there was more. Ooh I bet you want to watch the anime now after that huh?

If you like children, calligraphy, and a bit of comedy mixed in, then this show is for you. It doesn't necessarily have deep moments, but it is a great anime!
A guy, who has a passion for calligraphy, gets sent to an island and makes friends with the villagers. An island? You can't help but think "why, an island?" But even so, it is an island full of friendly villagers. 
Every second of the series makes you laugh. You can't help but find the protagonist's interactions with the children hilarious and adorable. 
Everybody makes mistakes. And everybody isn't a Mary-Sue/Gary Stu. It is rare to findanime that has characters with flaws. For example, Handa Seishuu learns and grows as a character. He makes mistakes and tries to reflect on what he has done.\n\n
I just like the interactions of Handa and the rest of the villagers. It is heart-warming to watch. So if you're looking for an anime to watch and like a bit of comedy and relaxation, then this is for you! \n

Never ever have I enjoyed a slice of life comedy series then Barakamon, nor have I ever genuinely laughed to an anime because of it being so relatable. Barakamon even proves that to enjoy an anime you don't need to do the normie bullshit that every other series out there does.
Barakamon is about the story of, Handa Sei, who is a calligrapher and ends up going to a island in the middle of nowhere after punching the Art Gallery director because of Handa's style being textbook, and once he gets there things change for the best for him, and those around him.
The art is oneof the best things about this show. The character designs are great, the characters all fit the theme of the environment to the show, and even when other characters from when Handa was in Tokyo to visit, even had a realistic element to the country, as it was something it was not used to, and the art depicted the emotions, actions, and the environment to a degree that it almost felt like you were with them in the story, living it yourself.


The sound I would say is great basically for the same reason as the art, like seriously, you CAN'T beat how well the voice actors did on this show. It was awesome. Even the little kids in the show, that Handa ends up taking care of all the time has a perfect voice that just isn't even hateable, and most Slice of Life Comedy series end up making me hate those characters. The opening and ending are also very good in this series and you can't help but get into the show after it.


The characters in Barakamon are wonderful. I mean, I've never ever had a series where I can literally no matter what, not dislike a cast of the show. It was just crazy to me, all the characters are lovable, even though they all do have their own share of problems, the people around them all pitched in and a lot of the characters had their own backstory that was even introduced in the anime and wasn't even dragged on for too long, it got to the point, at the right time, and was very enjoyable and was touching for the instances it was brought. It wasn't just poof a dumb problem arises and you need to know about what happened to them, it was realistic events bringing about ways that most people would figure stuff out. The community in the show is more like any other as well.


My overall enjoyment level of this series was literally binge watching and wondering why the hell there isn't anymore episodes and I need more now type enjoyment level, I was that enjoyed while watching Barakamon. It had the laughs, it had the ups and downs, it had the growth and development, and it was really all I could ever ask for in a Slice of Life, let alone anime in general. 



Overall, Barakmon is a MUST WATCH in my opinion to people who like the genre and anime in general. Its a nice change of pace and a show that generally anyone can get into. My friend HATES anime but couldn't stop watching Barakmon with me. If you're even reading to this point on if you should watch the series, just go ahead and do it now, because seriously, don't miss out on this Slice of Life that can set the stone for others of the same genre.

Barakamon review
Naru is cuteand natural way with the help of the characters who are in fact the story for this anime.


Story 7/10 

The story follows Handa  on a place very  new and unfamiliar to him for the purpose of improving his calligraphy skills, called the Goto island. The main theme this show abords is transition and it’s focused on Handa and how he interacts with the people and how those people influence his choices and help him change. On this island Handa experiences new things that he could not enjoy on his city lifestyle : making new friends, enjoying the beauty of nature, picking fights with grade-school kids, catching beetles and going through a plethora of experiences on the island. On the surface this may seem for many just a way to relax and forget about life problems but all he does and the characters that he interacts with   have a purpose and meaning  in improving his calligraphy skills later .


The pace of the story is not rushed at all , from the very beginning it’s able to maintain a balanced atmosphere.Handa learns on his own skin how different the life is on that island from his city life and the show evidentiate his frustration also his curiosity to discover and learn new things.We are introduced to the picturesque peisage of the island ,the old traditional houses, we get to meet the people living in that village, their story and circumstances, the way they make a living majority of them from fishing  and finally the silent and relaxing sound of nature which calms our hearts and captivates us. These are the strong points of Barakamon the characters and their surroundings and everything is kept simple ,and Barakamon is a good example that simple is good sometimes for the story and character development.


Barakamon has his unique style with his characters , many of them living a simple life on that island  and many characters having different gaps of age.  Barakamon manages to shine as a slice of life anime because of the way he is able to create the connection and relation between those gap ages characters(kids, high school students, elders) and use them as a whole for the story and  to influence Handa directly or indirectly.

Another interesting concept aborded by this anime is the fact how a person can change and adapt to a new lifestyle and how the experiences in that new life style helps him improve as a person.This really gives credits to the saying “As long as we are alive we learn new things everyday  until the moment we die”.


The most impressive aspect of this anime is the balance between heart-touching moments and comedy. It’s so well done that everything seems so natural and flows like a river along his course in this case our story.


Characters  9/10 

The characters are the story in Barakamon and we have a diversity of characters in this anime and a strong point is how the show manages to use them to influence Handa directly or indirectly affecting his decisions and thoughts. 


Handa is the main character , he is a calligrapher and at first glance he may seem a serious and mature person but deep down in his heart he is a child. These statement is true when he plays with the kids from the island and explores with them new places learning about their lives and circumtances. These adds a tone a maturity to the show despite the kid characters.Every new experience helps Handa and those minor details are well evidentiated by Barakamon and not casted away helping him reap the fruits of his work ,in this case improving his calligraphy style. 



Naru is a little devil who always likes to play pranks on Handa and play with him. She acts exactly like a 7 years old kid is supposed to act , she is spoiled , gets dirty after she plays all day, collects snails and everything is done in a normal and  natural pace by Barakamon.Despite her child behavior and age she sometimes brings a tone of maturity to the show and manages to help I her own way  Handa  to overcome his calligraphy hiatus . This is why Barakamon shines with his characters and manages to impress me as a viewer showing us a lesson of life that kids can help adults in their own way and bring a smile on the face when we are face with the hardships of life.


Other characters are mentionable too we have the Arai symblings who one of them is a hardcore fujoshi , Hiroshi who is Handa’s new neighbour   who helps him in dire situations , and the other villagers and their families. Barakamon manages despite his high number of characters and limited space(12 eps) to develop each of them and the connections and interactions between them is done in a natural flow for the story.   All of those characters help Handa and influence him directly or indirectly in improving his calligraphy skills  in the end.


A major impact on this anime are the kids  with Naru as their pesky leader and despite that Barakamon  still maintains his aura of mature anime because of the way it’s executes his plot and story with those characters.


Animation 9/10 

Unique animation for each character , stunning visuals for the peisage  which captivates the viewer .


Sound 9/10

The sound and ost fits perfectly with the peisage , characters actions and brings  tons of feels to the viewer. The opening is great  and it’s a good method to overcome a bad day you have when you are sad .


Enjoyment 10/10 

I laughed , I cried, I felt connected to some characters and I saw a great slice of life anime. Also Naru made me forget about my bad day and showed me how beautiful and yet simple life can be if you enjoy it.


Overall 9/10 

Great slice of life anime with a impactful message to the viewer , stunning visuals  and sound that captivates the viewer and as a conclusion well all learn new things form different persons like this anime evidentiates.

A cute story about a 23 year old young man Handa who we learn has been studying most of his young life to be a calligrapher, as his father was before him.  His father insults his latest calligraphy work and Handa blows his stack and strikes his father, storming out of the room.  Later, it is decided that Handa should spend some time contemplating in a village on a remote island that the father has connections with.
Once he arrives, he tries to settle in and take in the solitude and isolation, hoping for inspiration and a change of heart.  But he's infor a surprise when he soon discovers that the entire village is interested in him, from the kids to the elderly.  The story really begins with him developing relationships with the simple but lovable people of the village, who call him Sensei due to his respected role as a calligrapher.\n
This is a human interest story, pure and simple.  Not much actually happens in terms of plot -- Handa needs to develop maturity and his own style of calligraphy.  The more he tries to push away his nosy admirers, the more they are determined to get know him better.  In the end he discovers the childhood he missed while studying so hard on his vocation, and hilarity ensues as the villagers try to include him in their daily life.\n
The little girl Naru steals the show with her impishness, quirky precociousness, and her genuine affection for Handa-sensei.  The other close supporting characters, Miwa, Tama, Hina, Hiroshi and the village chief create an ad-hoc family for Handa, for which he seems to only vaguely appreciate.  However, he needs them more than he realizes, and most of the story develops around Handa learning to be a member of a close-knit community and not an isolated loner.\n
I really enjoyed this story.  I think it was well written, and the writers did a good job of bringing real humanity to all the core members of the story.  I would love to see a second season where we could see more the people we grew intimate with in the first season.  Definitely recommend if you like a good comedy-drama mix.
