WATCH BARAKAMON

This is a very happy go lucky kind of anime. It follows the common "hard work + perseverance = results" trope but with its fantastic characters and heartwarming tone it accomplishes what many other anime fail.
The story is nothing special pretty much just slice of life but with an over arching goal. The real shine comes from the characters which all translate emotion great. From the first episode you will want to see more of Naru, the primary supporting cast member. Most other characters also work well and are what makes this anime so heartwarming.
The other success of this anime is tone. Often tone iswhere anime falls flat, either becoming too serious or directionless. However Barakamon maintains a feel good tone throughout only pausing to create tension usually hinged on the risk of losing this atmosphere. This works well to keep the watcher engaged while remaining relaxed.\n\n
If you are looking for a comfy anime this is a great option 8/10

this is one of other anime that would make you think
"ah life really is beautiful.."
it's my second time watching and decided to write my thoughts about this beautiful anime~
for me it's not an anime that only make you 'feel something', but also make you want to 'do something' too. for you who dislike children, you might changed your perception after watching this anime!
a quick synopsis:
it's a story about Handa Seishuu, a renowned young calligrapher with a narcisstic prideful attitude. one day an oldman veteran on the calligraphy field criticize Handa's award-winning work for being too dull. then Handa snapped and punch that oldgeezer for dissinghis work.\n
as a self-reflection punishment, his father sent him to a countryside island where he later surrounded by kids and opened his mind.\n\n
Story [9/10]\n
overall it's great! the way they make a wise expression through different point of view is really heartwarming. the theme of calligraphy itself is also interesting. it will gives you new experience. the comedy fit just good. and the best part is this countryside atmosphere somehow gives you a peace of mind.\n\n
Art [10/10]\n
perfect. the animation is great, but what makes me think it's perfect is the calligraphy. i'm not an expert in that field, but after watching this series, i came to think how beautiful calligraphy can be. it will make you realize, behind a great piece-of-art, there's always a story of the artist behind those artwork, that's what makes art really complicated and beautiful.\n
a good quality artwork is not only about skill and technique, but also the journey of the artist to encounter those ideas, a lot of trials and errors until it become a masterpiece. seeing Handa working hard on it really admiriing & inspirable.\n\n
Character [9/10]\n
**i recommend to watch "Handa-kun", a prequel of Handa's high-school day. it's not related to the main story but you will understand more about Handa's character.* \n
he's not your usual 'ikemen' type of character, for a MC he's quite unusual and awkward, but that's what makes Barakamon really fun!\n
the variety of supporting character also great. it makes you want to believe that a pure-kindhearted-soul person still exist out there~\n
the silliness between the character is fun and heartening. you'all know how annoying and noisy kids can be, after watching this, i came to believe kids is not all about annoying after all. Sometimes the kids perception in life and their pure-innocence can be a good inspiration and motivation.\n\n
Overall [9/10]\n
what Barakamon lacks: 12eps is too few.. \n
but it's a good series to cheer you up if you're having a bad day!\n
enjoyable, heartwarming, funny, inspiring, relaxing\n
you can warm your heart even without romance there :)\n
it's worth to watch!

Barakamon is just too good!
So long story short, it revolves around something boring, calligraphy. However, what makes the anime so good is actually the characters.
The anime doesn’t really have a plot, what I love about it is the fact that every episode is pretty casual, not really plot driven allowing it to focus on character development which ultimately allows the characters to reach the final goal of the anime.
Handa is a well known calligraphist that writes his calligraphies by the book and apparently got dissed on because he doesn’t have his own style of writing. He got angry at the director that dissed him andpunched him. He was then sent to an island to ‘find his style’. 


He met the island residents, lived with them and slowly made his way to perfecting an individual self portrayed calligraphy style. 


It’s actually pretty heart warming to watch as Handa slowly gets used to the country-side life and sort of escape from city life.



What I love the most though is the characters. 

Handa met a kid named Naru, she is a cute little girl that has a boy’s character design for some reason, maybe it’s just me... but Naru is so damn cute, her voice is very cute and really fits her playful and always cheerful characteristic! 


Our MC is on the other hand, is someone full of pride and gets depressed easily. Sort of the complete opposite of Naru so Naru getting close to him and changing his characteristic to a more caring individual and a better person overall makes it especially heartwarming to watch!


The other characters (don’t want to spoil) all have very positive attitudes too so MC definitely would get influenced no matter how stubborn he is! And a huge thumbs up to the Seiyūs for doing such a great job bringing the characters to life!



I’d say overall, the anime was pretty enjoyable!

A review on what I believe is a really good series. 
No spoilers. No big revelations.
No analysis, just my feelings and a general impression - after watching it x1 and before watching it a 2nd time.
Just a few words that I hope will make you want to consider giving this Slice of Life a chance.
The only thing I’m not gonna talk about in superlatives is… animation. It isn’t bad, it’s actually pretty good. Yes, pretty good; just nothing mind-blowing! Guys, this isn’t a mecha!
Right off the bet, Barakamon is very touching — I’m not into Slice of Life and not easily moved by emotional anddramatic blah blah — and the dialogues feel really real. \n
The same goes for the characters themselves - TBH, there aren’t many. Every single one of them has an interesting personality that shines!\n
Naru and Handa are amazing! And if you don’t know who that is, look at the picture. I mean our main couple and just so you know, they aren’t a real couple, she’s too young to think about lovu-lovu! \n
Anyway, they help each other out a lot! Now, Naru’s just a child but that doesn’t stop the little girl from helping Handa (aka Sensei) grow. Their relation is to die for!\n\n
That being said, I got the impression that nothing was left out; every detail was considered. \n
Remember what I said - “my feelings, my impression”.\n
The comedy parts are gr8 and actually funny!\n
You can expect a lot of goofy moments.\n
You can expect a lot of sad moments, too. \n
The transmission from happy to sad is flawless. \n
Be prepared for sadness to fill your heart & be ready to smile!\n\n
Yes, you can expect a conclusion at the end of this show. \n
The ending is very satisfying - now, off you go! \n
Don’t waste your time on boring reviews.\n
For what it is, I’m rating this 9/10 + 1 (from my cheat-bag) to even the score… yes, I am ignoring mediocre animation. That’s not what I believe this Anime is about. The story’s what matters foremost!

"A beautiful wonderfully simplistic ride of emotions and motivation". This is what i would say to describe Barakamon in a sentence. 
Barakamon is a story about a calligrapher, who due to his narcissism and impulsiveness ends up on an island for some serious thinking. Story is as simple as it sounds and things will almost happen as you expect them to be, but what sets barakamon apart is its presentation. Story is wounded beautifully with main character in mind, his problems and other aspects of life are subtly explained with the help of side characters. Every episode is different and leads to character development inone way or another and also provides viewer a chance to grow as well. 


Art style is simple, nothing unique but soothing which resonates with the opening and ending songs as well as with the subtle background music.


Intriguing aspect about barakamon is character interaction. Characters are from all stages of life. In one episode you will see the energy and playfulness of a child and in other you will be experiencing the wisdom of old. Since story is mainly about the main character you will see little to no development in the character of side characters although most of them are kids and old people anyway which means they are either too young to develop a character or they already have a permanent one. These things are easily ignorable if you can relate with the main character which i believe most of us will. Story focuses on how main character interacts with side character and how they play their role in affecting his life for the better.


Personally i enjoyed it 100% and will recommend 100 out of 100 times. I wonder why i didn't watched it before.


So to sum up Barakamon is one of those anime you watch without any expectations but slowly turns out to be one of your favorites in the end. This happened to me during the second episode where i could see my failures right in front of me and after that it was one heck of a ride filled with elements of all the feelings.


Namaste!

As a thirteen episode slice-of-life anime there isn't much expectation and it's relaxed vibe, and comical plot, got me interested in it pretty quickly. I wasn't disappointed. 
The story is straight forward which, for once, I quite enjoyed and the goal of everything that happens on screen is also very obvious, and stated a few times. The art, to go along with this, is similarily straight forward and there are instanced where you can see where the budget was really well spent. Considering that, it's amazing how the consistency doesn't drop, but it doesn't which is also very nice. 
The opening and the ending goaccording to the overall theme of the anime and the art of the opening is just beautiful.  The rest of the sound is solid, though considering this can be also labeled a comedy anime you should know to expect a lot of sound bits to go according to the joke, face-expression, etc.\n\n
Personally, what I liked most about this anime is exactly the comedy of the moment, and then the storyline. The characters are all solid with their own aspirations, and the anime isn't afraid to poke at modern tropes like 'fujoshi fangirl' which got me rolling with laughter. \n
But, I warn you, this isn't anime to be watched twice. The comedic effect just isn't the same.\n\n
If you want a bit of relaxing after an intense anime, and if you want to laugh a lot, I suggest this one. I sincerely hope for season two.

Ah, slice of life. A genre that tends to hit-or-miss for me. It's amazing how sometimes anime about nothing can be absolutely great and a lot of fun or completely useless and boring. Thankfully, Barakamon goes for the former.
STORY (8/10):
Barakamon's story is nothing special as a concept, but the way the anime executes it is what makes it so great. The way our protagonist evolves throughout the series makes it into a captivating watch.
ART (8/10):
The series has quite above-average artwork on most occasions. However, it occasionally uses simplistic, childish designs, totally on purpose, in beautiful ways.  However, visual gags tend to be hit ormiss (there's one in episode 5 a lot of people disliked). 


SOUND (8/10):


The OP and ED are better than most anime, though nothing I'd go out of my way to listening to. The voice acting is really good, and I like the fact that the children are voiced by actual children, a rare occurrence in anime.


CHARACTER (8/10):


I mentioned earlier the protagonist's evolution throughout the series. It truly is something to see this loner workaholic change and come out of his shell as he becomes more comfortable with the people on the island. 


Naru also is forever on my list of favorite anime characters. She's just so cute, and the best portrayal of childhood innocence I've ever seen in anime.


There was one character I strongly disliked, and that was Seishuu's mother. Thankfully, she's only introduced in the final two episodes and plays a minor role. If she had stuck around any longer she would have hendered my enjoyment of the series quite a bit.


ENJOYMENT (8/10):


I am a naturally anxious person, and watching Barakamon helped me with that at times. Ah, the joys of a good slice of life.


OVERALL (8/10):


Overall, if you like slice of life, definitely watch Barakamon. If you don't like slice of life, still give Barakamon a shot. You'll be pleasantly surprised at the amount of story and character development this slice of life has - it's far from a show about nothing.


---


CONTENT ADVISORY: Some episodes are completely clean, while others have some mild language and suggestive humor. (Even still, the PG-13 rating on MAL seems a little strict.) The official subtitles from FUNimation are cleaner than the fansubs, so I'd go with those for younger viewers.

After the disappointing trash that was GJ-bu, I was in a supreme mood for a good comedy to help me find a reason to live (again). After a few minutes of debating with the pink monkeys in my mind on whether I should re-watch the first season of ‘Working!’, I suddenly remembered the little white shirted brat from some show called ‘Barakamon’ people could just not get of back when it released.
Thank you, white shirted kid who I thought was boy but I turned out to be a girl who kind of sounds like the son of a helium container, Barakamon was downright hilarious.
As thesynopsis shows, Barakamon is a slice-of-life comedy with just a tad bit of drama to start things off.


Handa is a brilliant and arrogant calligrapher who has won many prizes. One day, after receiving harsh criticism from an oldie calligrapher, Handa goes haywire and decks him withe rage of a thousand ones and a half. He is then kicked onto a remote island by his dad so he can reflect on his actions. When Handa arrives at his new home and meets the resident rascal, white shirted Naru, he can’t even imagine how loud and crazy his life is going to get.


And that’s pretty much it. There’s no over-arching plot or any visible goal that the anime’s story wants to go towards. Even though this is slice-of-life to a tee, the setting is somewhat unique so major props to that in an industry where slice-of-life comedies are as common as atheists in a Neon Genesis Evangelion forum.


There are no melodramatic events or scenes that reek of cheap laughter. Barakamon is a finely thought-out comedy centered on a creator’s re-invention of his style and the environment that helps mould his transformation. The gags are creative and plentiful. They don’t feel like they’ve been set up for laughs: they occur naturally as how they would in real life. A kid performs kancho (butt-stabbing) on Handa when he arrives at the village and gets told off his dad. Naru’s misunderstanding and repetition of bad words she hears the people around them say. Handa sulking childishly in a corner when he loses a competition. They feel real and illicit genuine laughter out of you. So in the comedy compartment, Barakamon excels with flying colors.


The many different events that happen over the course of Barakamon develop and flesh out the characters and the village as a whole so the storytelling is also top-notch. Even the very minor subtle things happening in the background of various scenes tell you a lot about the characters and the way they interact with other.


Speaking of characters, the cast of Barakamon is absolutely lovable and the characters reel you in very quickly with their debut appearances. Well, except for the kid who does kancho on Handa in the first episode. The supporting characters are based on stereotypes but are fleshed out so well and given individual attention so much that they don’t even seem like supporting characters by the end of the show.


Handa goes from a downright narcissistic busybody ‘no fun allowed’ impulse driven man-child to a lovable person who deeply worries about and cares for the people around him on the island – while growing as an artist and learning about the joys and pains of an unrestricted life. Naru is boisterous and mischievous to the core and really enjoys annoying Handa and making him play with her while Hina, Naru’s friend, usually cries and is rather clumsy.


The children feel like they are actual children. From their voices to the way they behave with both each other and the grown-ups of the show, you know a lot of heart and soul went into them and also because they are voiced by actual children – who have actual voice acting talent! They are VASTLY different from the usual fare of kids present in most anime.


Even the three teenagers of a rowdy girl athlete, a fujoshi, and a mature guy who is somewhat worried about his future after highschool are extremely fun and their personal fears, craziness, and quirks are given a spot in the light.


The animation is done by Kinema Citrus studio of ‘Tokyo Magnitude 8.0’ and ‘Yuyushiki’ fame. It bright and vibrant with a nice and warm contrast with colors and the backgrounds. The animation can go from very detailed to chibi-ish depending on what’s happening in a scene. It’s good stuff.


The background music… well, I don’t remember the background music which is kinda weird since I binged the show last night. I guess that means it was forgettable. The moody country-esque Opening was a delight to listen to. The quite straightforward Ending that sounds like a blast from 2001 highschool rock bands takes some getting used to – which isn’t a bad thing since the warm watercolor visuals are just calming to look at.


I really REALLY enjoyed Barakamon and it’s now in the top 15 of my list of anime comedies to recommend to people when they ask for suggestions. The problem I have with the show is that Naru should have had a much larger impact on events and more screen-time in the last two episodes (describing this in last paragraph as it’s a spoiler). Because of that and the thing with the background music, Barakamon is a swift 9/10 show for me. Highly recommended.


(In the last few episodes, Handa leaves the island out of the blue without saying goodbye and then returns in the same fashion. During his absence and after his return, Naru’s presence is pushed back to that of a background character’s. She gets relatively very little screen-time and the few lines she does say don’t have as much impact as they should for someone who was the main force in aiding the change in Handa’s calligraphy in personality. I feel she should have gotten a much more major role in the last episodes since she’s very important to Handa and vice versa. Just saying. This doesn’t mean that how the ending is handled isn’t bad by any means. It’s actually very good. It just could have been… much better, in my opinion.)

Easy start. It will make you immerse in it so naturally, every bit was so easy to watch, nothing felt forced or unnecessary (except of delaying of return to island...). It did great job with emotions. You could feel what main character flet. Not just one emotion, but culmination of them betwen every of these "breakthrough" secene (especcialy after first half of series). And I would say that that is this anime main future. Just how in depth it could make you feel these moments (not just some simple happy/sad emotions), and how inconspicuously it provided you with more insight to enjoy them. I reallyenjoyed it.


The reason why I don't give it 10, is that although it could invoke complex emotion, they still were on one side of spectrum.

And lastly, not problem with anime, but with my perverted mind, there were 2-3 parts where I just couldn't enjoy otherwise perfectly innocent scene.

Barakamon is an excellent anime that faithfully adapts it's source material.  It is with a slight bitterness that I have to give the series a 7, for reasons that feel a bit unfair even as I type them. I will do my best to explain exactly what those reasons are. But first, lets get a look at what Barakamon gets right, which turns out is almost all of it.
Slice of life anime is at its best when serving up slices of life that the viewer might not be familiar with. In this respect, Barakamon hits you on two fronts: Calligraphy and the Goto islands.When dealing with content that viewers are likely detached from in their real lives, producers must find a way to lasso interest from a skeptical audience.


They did a great fucking job. The Goto islands are brought to life beautifully with very colorful and beautiful animation. The story is focused and tight, grounded by an excellent cast of characters with fantastic personalities. I say this in every review: If I must criticize one thing about anime in general, it's that it often lacks focus and loses its way among the setting and cast. Barakamon does not even come close to committing such a grave error.


So how do the producers accomplish this? Simple. They anchor the two larger focal points of the show (The Goto islands and Calligraphy) onto two characters. Seishu Hanada is from the world of calligraphy, a man who lives and pains over his art form. Naru Kotoishi is a young rascal from the Goto islands, completely immersed in the distinct local cultural.


Each is clueless about the world of the other, but this provides the basis for their relationship. Each character impresses upon the other and teaches each other about their world. This dynamic also helps inform the audience, because while watching you tend to feel like you are learning about these two respective slices of life from people whom are experts. You are ignorant and they will teach you.


But Barakamon is more than just it's setting. If I were to illuminate the entire cast and their interwoven relationships, I could paint you a beautiful complex web of intermingling worlds. But then I would spoil every minor detail of the series and get my review taken down, so lets not. I'll just comment that the entire cast is charming and funny, and return to Naru and Hanada.


For Hanada, this story is more than just about his struggles with his calligraphy. He wants his own unique style, but this is just a symptom of his struggles as a human being. He is a flawed, talented person whose growth has been stunted by his relationship with his family, and his tendency to let his environment dictate his path in life. The great thing about him, is that he's not a hammy awful person. He doesn't start off as some painful tsundere archetype that makes you want to gag. Seishu Hanada could be any young man with emotional struggles, not totally beyond redemption, but clearly has some growing up to do. Naru, like she is a mentor of the Goto islands, is a mentor of emotional maturity to Hanada.


Did that last paragraph seem to end abruptly? I should hope so, because that's quite indicative of Barakamon's glaring issue as an adaptation. The two main characters and their relationship is supposed to be the pillars that hold up Barakamon. It very much begins this way. To be clear, this relationship never once falters. The chemistry between these two is impeccable, accompanied by a fantastic voice cast to bring them to life.


The issue is that the story slowly shifts from being about the two of them as pillars, and Naru begins to form a strong base on Hanada's pillar. The relationship is still there, and Hanadas story arc is VERY strong. However, Naru's importance to the story is shown in her importance to Hanada's arc, and she starts to lose her footing as an equal main character in the show. This one pillar holds the series up quite well, but you can't help but feel that things could have been better with Naru receiving her due attention.


"But the manga...!"


Stop right there fellow weeb. I agree entirely with what you are about to say, which is why this so frustrating. The creators nailed their pacing perfectly. They picked an excellent spot to end the first season, and handled their adaptation of the source material quite well. But therein lies our issue. The creators proceeded their adaptation as though they would get to adapt the entire manga. They even picked a great spot to end a hypothetical first season. Had this stellar crew been given a second season, my hunch is that this anime would sit on my top 10 list proudly. The previously mentioned issues with Naru's role would have also been irrelevant, as the story in the manga addresses this later. 


But because this anime is the complete work of Barakamon as an anime adaptation, it does not get the benefit of Barakamons complete story. You can pace your marathon perfectly, but it means little if the finish line is stolen from you. So in short: Watch Barakamon, it's fantastic, but read the manga to fill the tiny shortcoming that the anime will leave you with. A shortcoming it would not have if the whole story was told.

I came across Barakamon while browsing through the Anime list in MAL. Initally decided not to watch it as the premise didn't excite me. But gave it a try after some time and it simply ended up being the best slice of life anime for me!
Now to get into the review-
                     Story-8
As i mentioned earlier, the story in itself is not that captivating. The protogonist, Handa a caligrapher, is sent to an island by his father for mending his ways and discovering his own caligraphystyle.( the synopsis explains it really well so I'm not going into details). Caligraphy is all he has done in his entire life.

(a result of being brought up in such an environment by his father,who is also a caligrapher). He has no friends and has a hard time socialising with people(or rather hates it!). And the rest of the story is how  Handa gradually begins to open up his heart, have fun with the people in the island and matures both as a person and a caligrapher.



                     Art-10


The animation is outstanding! The characters(especially Naru), the island are all animated really well. It is definitely one of the best!



                      Sound-10


The opening and the ending songs capture the feel of the anime perfectly. 

Usually i skip the opening after watching 1 or 2 episodes but i couldn't do so with Barakamon! I just had to hear it before starting the episode!



                        Character-10


It's hard to find words to describe the characters! All of the characters are heart warming and just give off a vibe of positivity The main characters are Naru- A six year old kid and Handa  who get most of the screentime. Naru can be mistaken for a bothersome child at the begining, but boy she breathes life into the anime. Handa even though being an adult learns a lot from her as to how to have fun in life without worrying too much about the future. Humour is top notch in this anime. The predicament in which Handa is always put into by the cheekiness of Naru,Miwa and Tama are hilarious!

And the childish actions of Handa is a joy to watch. Its not only these characters, the side characters are also given appropriate screen time despite this being a short anime. It would not be wrong to say that characters make the anime what it is!! Anyways, I don"t want to dwell into the rest of the characters and make it a really long review!



 There was not even a single episode that couldn't make me laugh. But at the same time it was not just about the jokes but also the feelings this anime stimulates that makes it so good and enjoyable. I would say its a must watch for all anime lovers!!


This was my first review and if there were any shortcoming please highlight them. I would be more than happy to correct them next time!

[Spanish and English review]
English:
Why should you watch Barakamon? 
Because it is a relaxing anime, which also makes you laugh but sometimes drop a tear. The story takes place on an island, so you will be able to watch beatiful landscapes, with bright and cheerful colours. The characters are adorable: the main character, a caligrapher, learns a little bit about real life and friendship when he gets to meet the local people. Also if you are interested in japanese culture, you get to know a little bit more about what "shodo" is (the art of japanese calligraphy).
Why I love it? Because it cheers me up everytime I watch it (It's so sad that there is just one season!). I was able to know a different side of japanese culture, the country, with lovely people, and shodo. Finally, it reaminds me the important thing of life, the most important one besides work, success, or recognition: friendship. And, of course, I always enjoy Daisuke Ono's voice!.


Spanish:


Por qué hay que ver Barakamon? 

Porque es un animé muy relajante, que también te hace reír, así como, a veces, botar una pequeña lágrima. La historia se desarrolla en una isla, por lo que podrá ver hermosos paisajes, con colores brillantes y llenos de vida. Los personajes son adorables: el personaje principal, un calígrafo, aprende un poco más sobre la vida real y la amistad cuando se relaciona con los lugareños. Además, si está interesado en la cultura japonesa, puede aprender un poco más acerca de qué es el "shodo" (el arte japonés de la caligrafía).


Por qué me encanta? 

Porque me reanima cada vez que lo veo (¡Es lamentable que solo haya una temporada!). Me fue posible conocer un lado diferente de la cultura japonesa, el campo, con gente muy amable, y el shodo. Por último, me recuerda las cosas importantes de la vida, la más importante más allá del trabajo, el éxito, o el reconocimiento: la amistad. Y, por supuesto, ¡siempre disfruto al escuchar la voz de Daisuke Ono!
Fun, different and contagious energy, Barakamon is sensational, is proof that with a simple plot can make something spectacular, and of course Naru is anime soul.

(No spoilers)
Barakamon is a modern classic in the slice-of-life genre. There, I said it. Someone had to. Watching it you'll feel a slow smile creep up your face. It's about inspiration and the relationship between the characters. It's poignant at times without being pretentious or emotionally manipulative. 
The characters of any medium have to be relatable to cross that boundary of imaginary fiction and be a real meaningful figure. And barakamon has those characters. At the end you will become close with the characters as if you're part of the group too. Handa, our lead protagonist, is temperamental and moody like most people. He doesthings in the spur-of-the moment but also apologises after a realisation. He fails in finding inspirations for his profession of caligraphy but is determined to achieve something unique. The show mainly concerns with Handa chasing after his goal of finding his own style of caligraphy, and also the surrounding bond between the characters. Most characters support Handa in some way or are helped by him.


The most important and intresting one is Naru. Naru is our small child protagonist who is the biggest source of inspiration for Handa (directly or indirectly). Also, she's  a ball of sunshine who will have you smiling with her meme face and childish ways. In the show, you will slowly see her unravel and understand her. Credits to the small child who voice acted her, because she does a damn good job.


I've seen complaints about the character development of Handa, because each episode he seems to be taking a step forward and is back at the starting point in the next. That's missing the point. The development is supposed to be gradual. Each chapter is an anecdote. It's life and not some fairy tale (tail) where you just level up after being trapped in an island. And it's not as if the show just meanders around because the goal set out at first is achieved in some way. 


The other characters do contribute, however you won't see them grow as much as the other two. Well, they are the protagonists for a reason.


Barakamon in one word is charming. I mostly explore the slice-of-life genre in the medium of anime. Most people dismiss it as a genre of boredom where nothing happens. Barakamon sets out to prove those wrong.

(Greetings from Portugal!)  (overall Barakamon 9/10)
------------------------------------------------------------------ 
What a joy, what a pleasure!
Such a simple, emotional and inspiring story.
Being inspired isn’t easy and the world pressures you to always be inspired and creative.
The problem is: you can’t force yourself. The creative side of the brain doesn’t work like the rational part of it, working hard as you can might help, but doesn’t solve the artistic block. Seishuu Handa (the main character) is a young and promising calligrapher (yes that’s a thing and it’s quite interesting) that will learn to live slowly, far from the busy and troubling Tokyo. 
Life happens too fast, if we couldjust slow down and see the details of everything with the eyes of a child, we definitely would be satisfied and ready to improve (in anything) and grow. Being inspired is just a matter of being curious, I think.\n
The story is quite simple, the pacing of the show is remarkable and that is quite important for a slice of life show. There is definitely comedy and it’s good, far from stupid, the way I enjoy it the most. The realism is impressive and it appeals to me, the characters do the most ordinary tasks that can be done in the Goto island, in a very charming and heart-warming way. Seishu will discover a very simple way of living and a way of dealing with the 10x10^10 frustrations of being an artist (and in a deeper level, of being human and unsatisfied by nature).\n
The art fits the story and the setting beautifully. The 12 episodes are very enjoyable and relaxing (but not boring!) to watch, especially after a long day.\n\n
Thank you for reading my review.\n\n

Britt: Hi everyone. Today I'm going to be reviewing an anime I just recently finished called: Barakamon. Let me start off by saying that this anime is definitely one of my favorites, and before I even start reviewing it, I'm going to recommend it. But of course I'm going to give you the details and actually review the show. I'm just letting you all know now that I looooved this anime, and I'm going to explain why right now. Start the review! :D
Story: (Copied from "My Anime List")
"Seishuu Handa is an up-and-coming calligrapher: young, handsome, talented, and unfortunately, a narcissist to boot. When a veteranlabels his award-winning piece as "unoriginal," Seishuu quickly loses his cool with severe repercussions.


As punishment, and also in order to aid him in self-reflection, Seishuu's father exiles him to the Goto Islands, far from the comfortable Tokyo lifestyle the temperamental artist is used to. Now thrown into a rural setting, Seishuu must attempt to find new inspiration and develop his own unique art style—that is, if boisterous children (headed by the frisky Naru Kotoishi), fujoshi middle schoolers, and energetic old men stop barging into his house! The newest addition to the intimate and quirky Goto community only wants to get some work done, but the islands are far from the peaceful countryside he signed up for. Thanks to his wacky neighbors who are entirely incapable of minding their own business, the arrogant calligrapher learns so much more than he ever hoped to."


Yup. So basically the story is about a narcissistic calligrapher who gets sent to the country side to learn a thing or two about respect. While there he runs into the townsfolk, who are all very friendly people who welcome him there. He soon realizes that being with them makes him happy. Happier than he's ever been. He definitely learns his lesson of course. And funny enough, his best friend from the village is an energetic 6-7 year old girl that warms his heart. I think the story is very easy to understand, and it's very cute and not over the top. It's a slice of life anime, so expect random things to happen almost every episode. Episode 9 and 11 are particularly hilarious to me, though the whole show can be freaking hilarious at times, too.

I give the story a.....7/10 :)


Characters:

All the characters are likable. Even Seishuu with his narcissism is a really great character. Even all the nosy villagers and annoying children bothering Seishuu. Even the guy who's technically Seishuu's rival. They're all so likable! The main character is Seishuu Honda. A 23 year old calligrapher who deems himself perfect, till one day an older man called his work "unoriginal" or even "mediocre." Being the guy that he is, Seishuu punched the man in his face (no joke) then got sent to the countryside by his father so he could learn some sense. He's a pretty cool guy. He's annoyed by the villagers at first, but warms up to them soon. They all invade his privacy anyway, so gotta get used to them, right? He was a jerkwad at first, but he learned to not be such a perfectionist anymore. The people living there (mostly Naru) helped him realize his passion while also being a good person in the process. Moving me onto this next character: Naru Kotoishi. Naru is a loudmouth little girl who in all honesty, acts the way real kids do. She loves to play around, she loves bothering people, she loves going outside hanging with her friends, she loves receiving gifts and going to festivals and whatnot. I'd say the creators of the series hit the nail on the head with this girl. When she met Sensei--oh sorry. Forgot to mention that all the villagers forgot Seishuu's real name almost immediately, and just started calling him Sensei instead (he didn't seem to mind too much, though.) but yeah, when Naru met Sensei, I'd say she grew attached to him rather quickly. He's like a father-figure of sorts to her. He plays with her, gives her gifts, takes her to festivals and whatnot, and I could really feel the bond between these too. Naru is a very funny character. She's adorable, she's realistic, she's kindhearted, and she's super funny. I'm sure anyone watching this show would instantly fall in love with this girl. Moving onto the next characters, we have: Miwa Yamakura. A 14 year old tomboyish girl who has a key to Sensei's house so she enters whenever she pleases. She's not a very good influence on Naru. Naru often repeats Miwa's bad habits, causing Sensei to scold her. Next is Tamako Arai. Another 14 year old girl who's best friends with Miwa. She has a thing for writing yaoi (BL/ Boys Love) doujinshi, and also having odd fantasies when seeing two men together in the same place. She also has a spare key to Sensei's house. Next we have Hiroshi Kido; a high school student who's also the son of the village chief. He's a pretty average guy, who Tamako thinks would make an adoring boyfriend for Sensei. Wouldn't you know it, though? He also has a key to Sensei's house! We also have Hina Kubota. She's Naru's best friend, and she's a crybaby. When I say crybaby, I really mean it, too. The slightest touch to her arm could probably cause her to bawl her eyes out. She's still a cutey pie nonetheless. There are plenty and I mean PLENTY of other great characters to get to know, but I don't want to spend too much time on this section of the review. I'll just let you guys see them for yourselves ;)

I give the characters an 10/10


Art/Sound:

The opening theme song, titled "The LiBERTY", was performed by Fo'xTails, while the ending theme song, titled "HIDE-AND-SEEK", was performed by Kenichi Suzumura. I don't know anything about Kenichi or Fo'xTails, so I can't really recommend anymore of their music to you, but I enjoyed the opening and ending themes. Weeeeell, I think they both fit the anime pretty well, but they aren't my favorite songs in the world. They're far from terrible, they're just not my kind of music. They're kinda slow but fast at the same time if that makes sense. So, I don't hate either songs, but I don't love them, either. They're good and they fit the anime, so it's all fine. I don't remember much of the music playing in the background of the episodes though, so I can't give much detail on that. I watched this anime dubbed like I almost always do, and I think the characters voices were just fine as well. No complaints there. The art was decent enough, too. Like a lot of other anime, the opening and ending animations are usually....well....animated better than the actual episodes. I think this applies here. Now, the animation studio is: Diomedéa. I've...never heard of them before. I can't tell you what other shows they've animated that I've seen, since I honestly don't know. I think they did an average job here. The animation isn't perfect, like say Kyoto Animation, but it's not terrible, either. Sometimes the characters would look just fine, and other times they'd look awkward. Particularly on their feet. I can relate to this however since feet and hands are very difficult to draw, sometimes even professionals struggle with those parts of the body, but I'm not gonna lie. Sometimes the characters had some strange and ugly looking feet, haha. I give the sound a solid 6 out of 10, while the art gets a .7 out of 10. Not horrible, but not perfect, either.


Overall Enjoyment:

I loved it. I loved this show. What more can I really say? As I said at the start already: Yes. I recommend this anime to you. If you're sitting at home bored and just wanna watch a random, lighthearted, comedy, slice-of-life, cutesy anime, then this is the show for you! All the characters are likable, and they're pretty funny (especially Naru.) And this show is family friendly. So if you got some family members out there who enjoy anime like you do, I totally suggest watching this with them. I'm sure this awesome show will make you feel all warm and fuzzy inside once you finish it, and it's only 12 episodes! In short, this show was great and you should all definitely watch it if you haven't already. I give Barakamon a solid .9/10.


Hope you all enjoyed my review! :D

This will be my first ever review so sorry for any mistakes.
Barakamon is a refreshing easygoing anime. Something you don't need very much energy or attention to sit through. Nothing gets too heavy and the atmosphere is very lax.
Story: 7
The story of the show is quite simple, which is fitting for the mood of the show. The plot has no overall conflict and its really just 12 episodes of the characters playing around. The humor of the show is surprising enjoyable as well. 
Art: 8 
The art and animation are well done in terms of quality and the color is just as stunning. the useof light colors gives more of the feeling that they're in a rural town.


Sound: 7


Nothing much to say here. The sounds were fairly generic and while the ink splashes sounded great it didn't affect the overall show.


Character: 9


The characters in the show are all lovable. It works out even better when you put Handa who isn't very good at socializing with a bunch of country folk who are all very local with each other. It creates scenarios that you don't usually get with animes like these.


Enjoyment: 9


I gotta say the show was incredibly enjoyable and so were the characters. The humor is great and the setting is comfortable. However because the shows story doesn't have a plot line to go down the story can get repetitive.


Overall: 8


A very laid back and fun show to watch. Even if you're not into these kind of SoL 12 episodes of playing kind of animes, i still recommend you try Barakamon.
